PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Michael Beahan) took the chair at 12.30 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I received a letter from Senate Coulter resigning his place as a senator for the state of South Australia after the adjournment last night. Pursuant to the provisions of section 21 of the constitution, I have notified the Governor of South Australia of the vacancy in the representation of that state caused by the resignation. I table the documents.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Bob Collins)—by leave—agreed to:

That the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters be authorised to hold a private meeting during the sitting of the Senate on 21 November 1995 from 12.45 p.m. to 2 p.m. to consider matters relating to the committee's inquiry into push polling.
Consideration resumed from 20 November.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering the Broadcasting Services Amendment Bill 1994 [1995] as amended. When we last met, consideration of government amendments Nos 4, 11 and 14 were postponed. Is it the wish of the committee to now reconsider those amendments?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a procedural matter. I know that Senator Bob Collins was not here and therefore was not responsible; Senator Sherry was handling the matter yesterday afternoon. And Senator Collins can roll his eyes later if he wants to. We then had a discussion about the various implications of government amendments Nos 4, 11 and 14. We in fact agreed that we should not only defer them until a later hour that day but also subsequently defer them until the following day—being now—in order that each of us could have a briefing on the subject. I am simply wondering why no attempt was made to contact my office and therefore why that briefing did not go ahead.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —If you will just bear with me. I am sure Senator Alston will accept that I know nothing about this.
—Yes, I do.

—It is a little disconcerting, in the sense that I am trying to assist the committee, that, unfortunately, for whatever reason, none of the officers present was aware of this proposed arrangement either and I am advised that no such advice was in fact subsequently given to them. I do not dispute at all the story you have given me and at this stage I am not quite sure how this communication difficulty occurred.

PARA.TAB: I ask for your indulgence to perhaps suggest, so far as the opposition is concerned, what course of action would satisfy you. If an undertaking was given on behalf of the government for a briefing, I would have expected a briefing to have been provided. If it has not, then that matter will have to be redressed, I would have thought.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a result of the questions and answers in the committee stage yesterday, I indicated to the government in what it might call the briefing—the scrambled meeting at the back of the chamber—that I would be attempting to clarify the government's amendment by way of my own amendment. That should have been circulated to the offices of the various people involved. If it has not, I ask that it be circulated. I am talking about my amendment CW4048 of 2 March.
—I do not think I have it. By all means, go ahead, but I do not think I have it before me at the present time.

—Then I ask that it be circulated as quickly as possible. While that is happening, I will explain what it is about. There have been changes to it in response to certain concerns. Its rationale, as a result of the questions and answers yesterday, was to clarify the situation with regard to the government's amendment No. 14, the amendment that relates to the grandfathering provisions.

PARA.TAB: A question was asked about what the situation would be if the holder of interests in excess of 15 per cent changed their holding in any way, either above or below 15 per cent. Unfortunately, the answers given by the duty minister yesterday seemed to be at odds with what the Australian Democrats, the opposition and the Greens believed to be the case.

We believed that, while there was controversy about the original provision allowing a holding of more than 15 per cent, the understanding was that the holding would revert to 15 per cent if the interests of the holder were deliberately increased or decreased around that figure yet were still above 15 per cent. Unfortunately, the wording of the government's amendment does not make that clear.

In fact, whilst the amendment allows a managed trade down from the grandfathered figure to 15 per cent, there is an anomaly by which people would be allowed to deliberately trade up by other means, go back to 17 per cent and yet not be considered to have breached the provisions. Therefore, the grandfathering provision could not be used.

We do not think that entrenching privilege is the right way to go, nor that allowing a managed trade down is fair—despite the controversy about the original holdings of a particular person—nor that allowing it to be done in stages is fair. Allowing a grandfathering provision might well be considered to be fair. But for a person to deliberately trade up and then be required only to get down to a grandfathered position, and to be able to maintain a position of privilege even if they have deliberately traded up, seems to be ridiculous. We feel that needs to be clarified. That is what my amendment seeks to do.

Originally, we talked about the relevant person changing his or her company interests in the company referred to. In discussion with Senator Bourne from the Democrats, we have altered our position in response to their concerns to allow a managed trade down. In reality, our position is not much different from that of the government's. Obviously, there are penalties if a person exceeds 15 per cent. By logical extension, those penalties apply to the person who is grandfathered.

But the government's amendment does not clearly say that. There is an assumption that penalties are involved but it would be unwise not to clarify the situation. If the reality is that there is a penalty for trading above that grandfathered position, it would be a lot better to clarify the situation so that it is clear that deliberate trading up in any way will result in losing that privileged position.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a copy of Senator Margetts's amendment, and I have one question on a matter which I am not quite sure about. Until the minister's advisers have a copy, I probably cannot ask their opinion of it. Let me make a similar point to the one that Senator Margetts has made. I believe we were all concerned yesterday about the possibility of somebody deliberately increasing their company interests above where they were grandfathered to—above their privileged position. The minister's response yesterday, if I recall correctly, was to ask why you would do it because you would be in breach. You would only have to go back down and would possibly be fined a great deal of money for every day that you were over that limit. That is a good point. But if you were of the opinion that it would be very stupid for somebody to do it at all they have to have what they consider to be a good reason to do it.

PARA.TAB: The only reason I can think of would be if you were trying it on; if you wanted to see if you could get away with more. If that is the case, if no-one else can think of a really good reason—and I cannot imagine that anyone could—immediately you are in breach. You have deliberately put yourself in breach of the law by buying up. I cannot see why you would not have to immediately go back to where everyone else in Australia is: that is, with 15 per cent.

So I support Senator Margetts's amendment but I have one question. The last line of the amendment reads `that grandfathering provided for by this section is taken not to apply to the person'. I am not sure that that line achieves what we are trying to achieve. People sitting with the minister, who I assume are expert in this sort of drafting—which I am not and which, I suspect, Senator Margetts is not, because it is very difficult—may be able to tell me if this amendment achieves that. What we want to achieve is that, if a person deliberately puts himself in breach by going over the limit, he should have to go back to 15 per cent. A person can manage his holdings downwards towards the 15 per cent but cannot go back up again.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not actually clear to me precisely what the intent of the Greens' amendment is. I have not been able to get any clearer understanding of that from the officers because it is not clear to them either. I will return to that issue, but I would like to clear up the confusion over the point raised by Senator Alston. My advice is that Senator Alston's concern is a valid one. Briefings were, on advice, provided to the Greens and the Democrats. I assumed because Senator Alston is considered to be omniscient that he did not need a briefing. He was in fact entitled to one, and I apologise for that misunderstanding.

PARA.TAB: Could I ask for some procedural guidance? I regret that I was away yesterday and was not able to follow what happened in here. Would it be possible for the committee to consider voting on amendments Nos 4 and 11?

TALK.START.PARA: —We had that discussion yesterday when we were discussing the three amendments together. I think the idea that everybody agreed with was that we would vote on amendments 4 and 11 and vote on amendment 14 separately.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I address three or four issues at once? I am indebted to Senator Bob Collins for the information that he has provided to the Senate. I do not think there is any dispute from the other side of the chamber that there was an undertaking given to provide briefings to all relevant parties.

PARA.TAB: Whilst I am flattered at the suggestion that the omission might be due to some presumption of knowledge on our part, the more sinister explanation is that someone in the minister's office—perhaps not the advisers—took the view that, if the Democrats and the Greens were happy and onside, as prematurely reported in the Financial Review today, therefore, the numbers meant that there was no need to brief the opposition. That seems to me to be a more credible explanation, but at the same time a much more disappointing one because it suggests a cavalier attitude on the part of those who must have been aware of the undertaking given to provide a briefing, but who essentially ripped it up when they did not think it was necessary any longer.

Having said that, can I address the other issues that are currently before the Senate. It seems to me that what Senator Margetts has in mind is essentially that, where you deliberately—`voluntary' really is the term—breach the current arrangements or go above your floor level, then you ought to pay the penalty of being reduced to the statutory maximum of 15 per cent. Where it is accidental, Senator Margetts would, presumably, accept that the grandfathering arrangements proposed in amendment 14 would allow you to simply come back down to where you were, which is 17.2 per cent.

The spirit of that is certainly understandable and coherent. The difficulty in not having had the briefing is that we are not able to canvass whether Senator Margetts's amendment does stack up in achieving that or whether it adds very much to the sum total of what is sought to be achieved.

So I can say from the opposition's position that, because we take the view that all of this is piecemeal, there does not seem to be great merit in us, in effect, tightening or even clarifying the grandfathering provision when we essentially say that the grandfathering position and the new 15 per cent limit ought to be opposed. So, for that reason, I foreshadow that I would be opposed to your amendment, just as I would be opposed to amendment 14.

But in the event that amendments 4 and 11 are passed, then I may well take the view that we let amendment 14 through because I do not want a combination to result in any grandfathering being removed. If it is your position that even if your amendment fails you would still want to oppose amendment 14, then I think we would have to support it for all the wrong reasons.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I ought to add some explanation as well. It is very unfortunate that everybody seems to be informed by the media rather than by the people involved here. In the particular case of the article in the Financial Review that was reported today, it is unfortunate that the journalist involved rang and left a message and then rang back and spoke to someone in my office.

PARA.TAB: First of all, we clearly indicated in the meeting yesterday with the government advisers that there were elements that we were not happy with. I did make a mention in that meeting that I was preparing an amendment. I do not think anyone in the meeting would be unclear about the fact that I had an intention of preparing an amendment. Therefore, if there was any impression made to the media that everything was hunky-dory, it would have been a wrong impression.

The journalist himself last night contacted me and said, `I've written up this story and said that you are happy with it.' I said, `That's terrific. It would have been nice to check with me first.' The deadline had already passed. He changed the second edition, but he said, `I have to warn you that the edition that is coming to Canberra has you saying that you agree with it,' which is an interesting way of writing a story.

So I just thought I would clarify that. I have not been changing my mind every five minutes. It is simply that the journalist in question made an assumption that he was not entitled to make, wrote it in a story and it was too late to amend it by the time he had actually checked whether or not we were in that situation. We did not mean to keep anyone checking. That may well have caused or not caused any urgency to communicate with the opposition. But I would like to apologise and say that it was not of my doing.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Just very briefly, and this will be the last thing I will say on the subject: I am assured that those were the circumstances. I understand Senator Alston's concern. But, as he knows, there is an old axiom in this business which is more often right than wrong, and that is: if it is a choice between a conspiracy and a stuff-up, nine times out of 10 it is a stuff-up. I am assured, Senator Alston, that on this occasion it is one of the nine out of 10; it is not a conspiracy, as Senator Margetts has said.

PARA.TAB: In indicating that the government will not be supporting the amendment of the Greens—and to do this shortly—I might just briefly say that we simply feel that the proposals which have been put forward by the government deal with this matter effectively but also more equitably than by the Democrats. I understand now the context of the amendment, what it is designed to achieve; that is that, if there is a movement upwards, even a temporary fluctuation from 17 to 18 or 16 to 17, the grandfathering protection would be lost and—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, only if you did it deliberately.

—If you did it deliberately. But, of course, the government's amendment has the requirement for an ongoing penalty if that is, in fact, the case. We believe that is a fairer way of dealing with the same problem.

—I have just a brief point. The reason for our amendment is that we feel that that is, in fact, entrenching privilege. Because of the general principle of not changing something after a decision has been made, despite the controversy about whether or not that decision should ever have been made in the first place, we know that it was not an illegal act because the ABA, after long debate and public discussion, said, `Ah yes, technically it wasn't a problem because somebody else had a higher holding,' et cetera.

PARA.TAB: We know that the original decision was controversial. But to suggest that somebody could then change their interest to increase that and then be still protected by a grandfathering clause if they broke the conditions does seem to be entrenching privilege. That is the reason for this: to clarify the situation to ensure that we are not entrenching privilege, so that we can ensure equity eventually reigns and that any move is moved down so that everybody is treated fairly. I think that is the right thing to do.

If the government is preparing now to deal with 4 and 11 first, we would be happy to deal with it in that way. We will go the way the umpire decides. But it is important that people see the rationale by which major decisions on broadcasting are being made and whether or not equity is really the motive behind it. That is of great concern to us.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not, in fact—I can assure Senator Margetts and the committee—talking about entrenching privilege at all. We are simply talking about accepting a position which people took that was legal at the time they took it. I understand Senator Margetts's reference to her concern about not revisiting the original acquisition. We do not propose to revisit the original acquisition if the holding was made under the act as it was then constructed.
—It was not made under the act; it was appealed under the act.
—If the act was legal in terms of that acquisition, we do not think people should be penalised for that.
—Otherwise it's retrospective.
—Correct, it has a retrospective effect—and we are not supporting that.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That government amendments 4 and 11 be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment I have foreshadowed is to government amendment No. 14. I need to ask some questions of the government by way of clarification. We have had indications from the opposition and from the government.

PARA.TAB: This leaves us with a possible penalty. I need to find out, first of all, who actually decides the penalty and what is the basis upon which that penalty is decided. We have heard up to $2 million a day, but what is the likelihood and what kind of scenario could you envisage where $2 million a day would be imposed? What is the more likely scenario? Let us say, for instance, a person deliberately purchases or negotiates or manoeuvres to save one per cent more. What kind of penalty would you be expecting, if the government has the final say here?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Margetts, are you moving your amendment at this stage?
—I am asking a question by way of clarification.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —In terms of the extent of the penalty, you would have to direct that question to the judge. These decisions would, in fact, be taken by courts.
—What, the court?

—Absolutely. Ultimately a decision would be taken by a court with all of the rules and procedures that apply in that forum. The court would at the end of the day determine whether a breach had in fact occurred and the court would determine the extent to which a penalty would be applied.

—Minister, could you clarify this further. What court? Would there be an automatic referral to court? How would this happen? Would someone actually have to appeal? There is no automatic provision for a fine? This is quite important, really.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —If there was evidence that a breach of the act had occurred, the ABA—who else?—would initiate. The ABA would initiate action and the matter would be referred to the Federal Court. The Federal Court would determine whether a breach had, in fact, occurred and would then determine the extent of the penalty, if any, that would be applied. I understand the question, Senator Margetts. The ABA in the first instance would be the body that would determine whether there had been enough evidence to refer the matter to the Federal Court.
—I thank the minister. What guidelines are provided to a court in terms of how it would decide what kind of penalty is appropriate for what kind of breaches?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have thought a fairly substantive guideline is being provided to the court in the maximum penalty that has been set for an ongoing offence. The convention—I think it is well applied in courts—is that courts have regard to what parliament believes to be the severity of offences in considering maximum penalties. In this case those maximum penalties involve fines of up to $2 million per day for a continuing offence. That would be the guideline—
—The punishment fits the crime because of the severity of the issue.

—Precisely. My own view, I have to say, being the conservative about these issues that I freely confess I am, is that these matters are better left to courts to determine on all the evidence before them. As Senator Alston has said by way of interjection, to quote Gilbert and Sullivan, the punishment fits the crime. But the parliament is giving a very clear guideline to the court as to how severe we consider this offence to be, should it be proven, by imposing maximum penalties of up to $2 million per day.

—By way of further clarification, does that mean that if a court finds that a person is in breach the fine will be effective from the moment that person was in breach or from the moment that the court found the person to be in breach? This is quite important. It could involve a complex court case and it could go for a considerable length of time. Is it possible that the person in breach is allowed to keep those holdings and then is fined from the time the court finds a breach or, if it is a long court case, can the person be retrospectively fined from the time they were considered by the court to be in breach? This is quite complex. It is important to see whether what you have decided on is a fair grandfathering clause.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Exactly the same rules apply to this as would apply in the case of murder. The murderer is guilty from the day the murder was committed. The same thing applies here. That is why I would imagine that the companies involved in this case would be scrupulously careful that they did not deliberately flout the law. Senator Alston would confirm, as a lawyer, that that act of deliberate intent is also something that the courts could take into consideration in determining the guilt or otherwise of a company.

PARA.TAB: I can assure Senator Margetts that should a company be found guilty then that guilt would be from the day the breach occurred and for each day thereafter. That would be the maximum penalty that a court would be able to apply. As Senator Alston has said by way of interjection, all of the circumstances of the case would clearly be taken into consideration by a court in determining how much of that maximum penalty to apply in any individual case. The offence would be deemed to have been committed from the day the breach occurred.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where does it refer to that penalty applying equally to people involved with grandfathering and those people under 15 per cent?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Margetts will find the relevant information at subsection 66(2) on page 31 of the act. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: A person who breaches subsection (1) is guilty of a separate offence in respect of each day (including a day of a conviction—
so it actually applies up until the day the matter is adjudicated by the court—
under this subsection or any subsequent day) during which the breach of Division 2, 3, 4 or 5 continues.
The act is quite specific that it is not only each and every day from when the offence is committed but also each and every day up to and including the day of conviction being recorded by a court.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister, but that was not actually the question. Where does it actually refer to the person on grandfathering being subject to those provisions?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not understand the question, Senator Margetts. That is the penalty provision for a breach of the act. The grandfathering is deliberately designed to provide an exemption, under particular circumstances, from that penalty.
—But the act specifically says the breach is at 15 per cent, does it not?

—That is correct. We are also talking about control. We are actually changing the provisions of the act. That is what this amendment is all about. That is the penalty section in the act as it is currently constructed. The grandfathering provision that we are now debating, which will become a part of the act if it is passed by the parliament, will provide an exemption from those provisions as it is deliberately designed to do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is probably best to put my amendment now. I guess it will be on everybody's heads in relation to what is seen and what other people will see as being entrenched privilege in this particular case. If there is any lack of clarity, I guess we will see it later on in court cases, for which we will all pay. Therefore, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: After proposed subclause 9(4), insert the following subclause:

"(4A) If, after the commencement of this section, the relevant person increases his or her company interests in a company referred to in this section (other than an increase of the kind referred to in paragraph (3)(b)) and that increase is voluntary or could have been prevented by the person, the grandfathering provided for by this section is taken not to apply to the person.".

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I ask the minister to elaborate on his comments prior to the vote on the government's amendments, when he said that Senator Margetts's amendment would create a retrospective effect.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —To be blunt, having had an opportunity now to read Senator Margetts's amendment, I actually do not think that it will accomplish what Senator Margetts is, in fact, intending it to accomplish. That is simply a view that I have—that it possibly does not get there.

PARA.TAB: As I understood Senator Margetts's intent, as she expressed it during the debate, this is designed to cover a situation where, if a person who had acquired an interest which exceeded 15 per cent then increased that interest from 16 to 17 per cent, or 17 to 18 per cent, that person would not be dealt with in the way the government amendment deals with that additional equity, but that person would be caught up by this amendment in that they would have to go back to 15 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—Yes, that is correct. That is my understanding, Senator Harradine. Senator Margetts is indicating her assent to that; that is, that they would not then be considered to be holding the original 17 per cent at the time that this was constructed.

PARA.TAB: Senator Margetts interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes. We disagree with that, Senator Harradine, as I said to Senator Margetts. I must say that from my reading of the amendment I am not quite sure that it actually achieves that, but I am grateful to Senator Margetts for indicating by that interjection that that is indeed the intent. That is what I meant, Senator Harradine, when I said that this amendment would therefore have a retrospective effect, which the government is not seeking to achieve.

PARA.TAB: What we are seeking to achieve is that if a person's legal rights—Senator Margetts refers to it as entrenched privilege, and that is not the view the government takes—and equity are deliberately exceeded, then if a court finds that a person is guilty of doing that, they are penalised by a continuing penalty of up to $2 million a day for that offence. Senator Margetts wants to, as she said, extend that. As I say, I doubt that the amendment actually achieves that effect, but that is what I meant by retrospectivity.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can explain further. The design is to have a punitive effect rather than a retrospective effect. It is not making a person do something right now; it is just giving a signal that, if you do trade up, then you are no longer protected by the grandfathering. Basically, it is giving a general principle that everybody should be treated alike, but that there is a recognition that forcing a person to trade down because it is felt necessary to clarify a situation is retrospective. It simply gives a notice; it does not force anyone to do anything. Therefore, it is not retrospective, but it does give a punitive effect by saying, if you now trade up, there is an outcome. The outcome is that you are treated like everybody else. That is not retrospective; it is punitive. It is not retrospective because it does not force anyone now to do anything. It actually gives them a choice of what they do and what the outcomes will be if they take certain actions.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief. I understand that, Senator Margetts. I understand where you are trying to go with this amendment, but it is attempting to set up this new category of people who voluntarily increase their holdings. That would be an interesting matter for a court to determine. I point out the obvious: we believe that the way in which the government's amendment is currently constructed is the fairest and most equitable way of dealing with it—that is, providing a penalty for where that increase in equity is deliberate.

PARA.TAB: I am trying to construct a situation which I suppose could occur that is caught up by your amendment. If the ABA initiated legal action and they felt there was a case, obviously, they would take legal advice, and always do, before proceeding with such action. If a court subsequently found that a person had not deliberately done that, the court would behave appropriately. From a government perspective—that is why I said I think ours is more equitable—I think that is the correct position. If a person has done this inadvertently—I am trying to construct in my own head a situation where this could occur and it is very difficult—and a court, with all of the checks and balances that our courts have, finds that that person has not been directly responsible for this and there has been a temporary fluctuation—

TALK.START.PARA: —It's caught by this.
—That is correct; it is caught by your amendment and we are saying that we do not think it should be. Are you saying that it increases voluntarily or could have been prevented by the person?
—Yes.

—All I am trying to say is that I think it is a very confusing amendment. I appreciate your clarification that that is your intent and we do not agree with it, but I also doubt very much whether the confused way in which this amendment is drafted actually achieves it. In any case, for either reason, we will be voting against it.

—This is very confused legislation anyway because it is a very confused subject and it is very detailed and convoluted and difficult. I understand it is difficult to draft anyway and I think the drafting has been well done. But I do not think there is a problem with this amendment in that it creates an extra category. It does not create an extra category. The category of somebody who increases their company interests voluntarily is already there. The question is: what happens to that person if they do it?

PARA.TAB: Under Senator Margetts's amendment, what would happen to that person is what the three of us—what Senator Margetts, Senator Alston and I—had assumed up until yesterday was the case under the government's amendments. If this person voluntarily—and that person already exists under the legislation—trading up—

TALK.START.PARA: —Violates the law.

—That is right. Then what would happen to that person under this amendment? The intent of this amendment is that that person would then have to take their company interests down to 15 per cent. Under the current legislation, as the amendments that the government has put up, that person, the category of which already exists, would have to take their shareholding back down to where they were grandfathered at rather than the 15 per cent in the principal act.

PARA.TAB: There is no extra person or extra category of people involved in this. It is not confusing because there is something else invented. All it does is take us to the situation all of us thought we were in yesterday. That is what this is designed to do. I do not think it is designed to confuse anybody. It is designed to come back to the situation that we all thought we were in yesterday. I do not know about Senator Alston, but certainly Senator Margetts and I agreed that this was a reasonable situation. I cannot see that this is more confusing than what we already have in government amendments.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think we can take this much further, but I simply want to clarify from the government's perspective that the government's position—I know it differs from the position adopted by Senator Margetts—is that, if companies have legitimately acquired these interests as of 27 June, they can continue to hold them. Our amendments deter, I think very effectively, a person from deliberately increasing their interests after 27 June.

PARA.TAB: The government amendments, frankly, do it a lot more clearly and in a less confused way than this amendment, which is why we are pressing the government amendments. I think that is the appropriate way to deal with this. The government amendments do achieve—and no-one is arguing that—that, if people deliberately acquire additional interests after 27 June and if a court finds that they in fact have been guilty of the offence, they will be penalised to the tune of $2 million of continuing penalty per day for the offence—

TALK.START.PARA: —Up to.
—Yes, up to—and I have no problem with that either. I imagine that you would like to make that $2 million a mandatory penalty.
—No, when you say penalise to $2 million, that is not true. It is `up to', and that is no guarantee that that is the penalty.
—That is a standard form of expression in legislation. When they say $10, it means the maximum penalty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take up from where I was yesterday on the Airports Bill 1995. I remind the Senate that for people in regional areas in particular this is a very vital bill. We should be very careful not to act in a way that we will regret.

PARA.TAB: The purpose of the Airports Bill, as outlined in the explanatory memorandum, is to establish the regulatory arrangement to apply to the airports currently owned and operated by the FAC and to the Sydney West airport following the leasing of those airports. As we all know, it is meant, first of all, to govern the sale of Sydney and Sydney West airports and the Melbourne and Brisbane airports, but the other FAC owned airports, including the Hobart and Launceston airports, will come into line.

The bill provides that an airport lease will have a term of no longer than 50 years with an option to renew for up to 49 years—we are talking long-term arrangements—and that each airport will be operated by a separate company which must not undertake substantial trading or financial activities other than activities related to the development and/or operation of the airport or activities incidental to that purpose. Restrictions will apply to the transfer of airport leases, primarily to ensure the integrity of the public interest regulatory controls set out in the bill.

I do acknowledge that the government has put its mind to the question of regulatory controls, but the clear principle is whether that will be good for the travelling public—will it benefit or damage the economy in the areas concerned? Being a senator from the state of Tasmania, I am concerned with the fact that eventually—by 1997, I think—the FAC owned airports in Hobart and Launceston will be sold and privatised. My concern of course is that an economy such as Tasmania's, which is largely dependent on sea and air links, could be enormously damaged if travellers or freight were burdened with a quasi tax—caused by privatisation—in the form of higher airport charges on flights to and from Tasmania. That is the essence of it.

What we have here is a monopoly, and I raised this matter with the minister at an estimates committee early last year. But the minister responded by saying, `No, we are attempting to create competition.' Of course, competition is an essential plank of the micro-economic reform. Does the government mean that there will be competition between Hobart and Launceston airports? That is ludicrous—competition indeed! Are they suggesting that people are going to drive from Launceston to Hobart, or vice versa—which is a 2 1/2-hour journey—and catch a flight because it may be marginally cheaper as some sort of arrangement had been achieved? It is nonsense to suggest that the competitive element is there—that plank of micro-economic reform just is not there.

I believe that there is an inherent conflict between the following two principles: the government's desire to maximise the sale proceeds from the disposal of airports, and the government's objective of economic efficiency—that is, of providing infrastructure to all comers at marginal cost. Infrastructure such as airports should be governed so as to provide a service to all comers at marginal cost. If that principle is not followed, then this legislation, while it may not be doomed to failure, will mean that the people concerned will carry heavier economic burdens. That is what really worries me. It is something that I have been raising with the minister, as I said, since early last year, and I will continue to raise it.

Let us have a look at the first principle—the desire on the part of the government to maximise the sale proceeds from the disposal of airports. That is a legitimate desire, because the airports have been paid for by the taxpayers and the travelling public. They have been paid for, so you have to get a reasonable result from the sale.

We are being asked by the government to pass this piece of legislation which will give the go-ahead, the green light, for the sale of huge, very expensive and crucial tracts of land within Australia to private enterprise. We are being asked to do that without knowing and without being told the results of the scoping studies. I have been asking the government for quite a long time, `Can't we get the scoping studies so that we will be able to see and be able to assess within our offices whether or not the price that is likely to be paid by the bidders for the airports is appropriate and whether it reflects appropriately the input by taxpayers, the travelling public and industry up until this point in time?'

Not having really been given satisfaction on this particular matter, I wrote to the state government and referred the state government to my questions and letter to Minister Brereton. In that letter of April 1995 I did ask him in the last sentence:

SPEECH.PARA: I, therefore, request that full details of the scoping study for the sale of the airports be made publicly available as soon as possible and be presented to parliament at the earliest opportunity.
I sent a copy of that letter to a number of people, including the Premier of Tasmania, from whom I received a letter which states:

PARA.TAB: I share your concern for Tasmania and advise that the position, in relation to the State's particular vulnerability, has been clearly articulated in our responses to the Scoping and Regulatory Study Task force.

SPEECH.PARA: He goes on and indicates that his government has met on a number of occasions with, and written to, the minister requesting the results of the scoping and regulatory studies. He indicates in the fourth paragraph:

PARA.TAB: While the leasehold sale process ensures the Federal Government remains as "ultimate guarantor", its obligations and the wider strategic and regional development policy considerations which impact on the capital investment and operational decisions of the airports, will be removed.

SPEECH.PARA: He goes on:

PARA.TAB: In transferring its airports in Tasmania, the Federal Government must have particular regard to the importance of these facilities to Tasmania in terms of ensuring basic and equitable levels of access. As you know Tasmania's FAC airports are crucial components in the region's transport and economic infrastructure and provide critical passenger and freight links. As such, considerations of regional economic development, social equity, security of access and strategic importance are critical.

It is these considerations that may be removed or seriously jeopardised by the transfer of direct control from the Federal Government. Accordingly, arrangements at the point of airport transfer need to be put in place to ensure that these ongoing responsibilities of the Federal Government are not compromised.

SPEECH.PARA: I will not go on with the rest of the letter, but I would like to indicate to the government my concern that these matters have not been adequately dealt with by it in response to my interventions over a period of time. I would like to know what response the minister has given to the Tasmanian government in relation to the letter of the Tasmanian Premier in this regard.

PARA.TAB: I do say this: as I understand it and as the government has stated and restated the matter, micro-economic reform is all about improving efficiency and reducing costs. Quite frankly, I have some doubts about this. I know that there are a fair few people around this place who, if they could have their tongues loosened, would demonstrate that they also have some doubts about it. My doubts about it are directed not only at the activities of the federal government but also at the activities of state governments. State governments tend these days to boast about balanced budgets and that they no longer have the budget deficits they did have. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do understand Senator Harradine's concerns about the continued satisfactory operation of these two airports in Tasmania. I would confirm for Senator Harradine information which is already in the public domain: many of the government's own members have an equal interest—and I include myself in that category—in the airports in their own regions.

PARA.TAB: In the case of the Northern Territory, the key that unlocked the construction of our two superb terminal buildings in Alice Springs and Darwin—in the case of the Darwin terminal, after about half a century of lobbying to get a new airport terminal—was getting those airports put on the list of airports controlled by the Federal Airports Corporation when it was first established. If that had not happened, I think we probably would still be waiting for new airport terminals in Darwin and Alice Springs.

However, they resulted from a significant concession being made by the then finance minister, Peter Walsh—not someone who was entirely beloved in the Northern Territory. Nevertheless I have to say, and give public commendation at this point in saying it, that Senator Walsh's agreement to write off a significant portion of the debt from those airports was absolutely instrumental in getting the FAC to agree to construct both of those terminal buildings.

There is a great deal of concern and positive concern from government members as well. If it had not been for those concerns being allayed—and that is the point I wish to make—this legislation would never have proceeded. There was, in fact, a very active involvement by the members of the government's caucus in this issue. We have had firm assurances given on behalf of the government to all of those people—and I give those same assurances again to Senator Harradine—that the interests of the users of these airports will be protected.

The government will ensure that Tasmania's strategic interests are protected throughout the entire leasing process. Of course, as Senator Harradine knows, the proposal is that the Hobart and Launceston terminals will be dealt with in the second stage of airport disposals, which is scheduled for 1997-98. Federal and Tasmanian officials are participating already in a steering committee. Consultants have provided financial and technical advice on the infrastructure at Launceston and Hobart—on the needs of those airports—and the alternative ownership and management options that will be available for those airports.

I have no doubt, knowing the intense interest in airport operations in any community and the vital part that airports play in the life of any community now, that will be a very transparent process at Hobart and Launceston during the time that elapses between now and 1997-98. It may well be—I cannot know this in advance—that there will be active interest in the community itself owning the airports.

The only reason I make that point is that during the period of time when I was transport minister the Commonwealth handed over to local control literally hundreds of airports which had formerly, for reasons that escape me, been administered by the Commonwealth from Canberra—a fairly unwieldy situation I must say. It has been in many cases a source of great success and, I might say, pride for the local communities where the councils themselves have actually taken on the responsibility of airport ownership and the running of those airports. Indeed, at various times local government in the Northern Territory has expressed a strong interest. You could not at this point in time rule out that that may well be one of the options for these airports or indeed for other local governments. But that is all something for the future.

The steering committee is under way and the consultant reports are being provided. No doubt there will be more. The Commonwealth will continue to consult closely with local interest groups to ensure that all of the alternative options are canvassed fully and the implications of those options are fully understood.

The Commonwealth is well aware of the importance of these airports to Tasmania's infrastructure. Acknowledging Senator Harradine's concern, Tasmania is in a different position from mainland Australia in respect of both air and sea transport in that it does not have the alternatives readily available to mainland Australia in many places of road and rail. Therefore, this is an even more important concern for Tasmanians than perhaps it would be for other places where those alternatives are more readily available.

Accordingly, the specific characteristics of each airport, as well as regional and local community interests, will be taken into account when evaluating the leasing strategy and bids for these airports. As well as that positive and proactive involvement in the Commonwealth in this exercise, personally I, knowing the number of community groups with a direct active involvement in the impacts of an airport on any community, have no doubt that airport operators will have a considerable gauntlet to run, a very practical gauntlet to run, at each and every level of the community if they did for some reason intend to be unscrupulous or monopolistic in their behaviour to airport charges.

At the end of the day, that would go upwards and would include the body that keeps surveillance on prices. From a practical perspective, from my knowledge of airport operations and from the interest shown in them from tourist associations, local councils and everyone else, there would be a significant gauntlet for any airport operator, as a responsible member of that community, to run in respect of airport charges. I conclude my remarks on that point.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction. Is the minister aware of claims that the new Coastwatch contractor does not possess suitable equipment to fulfil the contract? If so, does the minister consider that these claims have any substance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of such claims which are being made by a Mr Warren Entsch, the Liberal candidate for the seat of Leichhardt in northern Queensland. He makes a number of claims in the press—none directed to me as the responsible minister, so the Senate can draw its own conclusions as to his motives—but then says that, because I have not rebuked him, his claims cannot be wrong. As he continues to make these false and misleading assertions, I will now use this opportunity to certainly put him straight.

PARA.TAB: His claims are wrong and they show either an unwillingness to take into account information I have already put on the public record on this matter or, more disturbingly, I presume he wishes to push these misinterpretations for his own political purposes.

The Islander plane used in the current contract in the Torres Strait certainly is not as fast and does not have the range of the Shrike in the previous contract. We do not have any argument with that. The inference that Mr Entsch then draws that it cannot meet the terms of the contract is totally incorrect. As conveyed to Senator MacGibbon on 28 August this year in response to his question on notice:

ANSWER.PARA: A Request for Proposal (RFP) process was used for the surveillance contracts because it was the best method of letting a complex contract. In the RFP process no specification is detailed as an essential premise is an ability to measure proposals against a requirement, then pick the one which best meets the overall needs. Performance requirements which must be met by the contractor are then written into the final contract. This is a different process from that found in the Request for Tender situation where a specification is published in the expectation that tenderers will fully comply with that specification.
So Mr Entsch's arguments about the capabilities of components in the integrated contract, in isolation from the total outcome, are misleading at best and deliberately mischievous at worst.

PARA.TAB: For the record, and particularly for Senator Macdonald, the performance differential in the Torres Strait sector with the previous contract is that, firstly, surveillance aircraft will fly 3,300 hours a year with the two Islander aircraft and slightly more crew, which is an eight per cent increase after the speed differential between the Islander aircraft and the Shrike used in the previous contract is taken into account. Secondly, at 400 hours a year there is a 27 per cent increase in helicopter flights, including flights now with night vision. Thirdly, in addition there will be 520 hours a year of flights by the Reims F406 aircraft, capable of night-time and electronic surveillance—a capability that was not in the previous contracts.

Consideration of surveillance as an integrated system and the improvement to this system that the new contracts will bring will result in an increase of visual surveillance coverage of around 26 per cent for the Torres Strait, which is the most intensively patrolled area in terms of Coastwatch activity. In addition, there will be a very substantial increase in electronic surveillance. This Coastwatch contract is certainly an increase in capability, especially for the Torres Strait. But, of course, we have the opposition, including Senator Macdonald, going around saying it is declining when in fact it has been increased.

I point out that in early October this year I inspected the Coastwatch operation in Torres Strait. I spoke to the officers from Coastwatch and asked them about Senator Macdonald's last effort in saying we should try to find a man in a red hat. Despite every effort, they could not find the man in the red hat. No-one has ever seen or heard of him.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Given the minister's answer, does he believe that Mr Entsch's call for an inquiry into this matter is justified?

—Like any responsible government agency, Coastwatch will monitor performance of this contract within the terms of the contract. That said, there is no evidence available to me to suggest that the contract is not advantageous to Australia in terms of the overall outcome. Accordingly, I reject firmly Mr Entsch's call for an inquiry. I ask him to stick to the facts. QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the cabinet decision to fund Dr Lawrence's costs and ask the minister: given that the government has made that decision, does it accept that it has a responsibility to contain public expenditure to levels which are genuinely fair and reasonable? —As to the first question, the government does believe that the costs payable should be at levels which are genuinely fair and reasonable. What we have said, however, is fair and reasonable as so certified by the Australian Government Solicitor, taking into account normal commercial practice and taking into account for that purpose the overall amount of the account, the nature of the work done, the size and experience of the legal team, the hourly rates charged by the solicitors and counsel, and the overall importance and complexity of the issues involved. That is the normal touchstone that we apply in these matters and that is what we have done here.

PARA.TAB: As to your second and third questions, the normal practice in the conduct of royal commissions has been to support, with legal cost payments, people appearing before those commissions, where they are principal witnesses or the principal target of the commissions, at a level which is significantly above that which is available for legal aid purposes. That has been the Commonwealth's practice in royal commission situations over the years and that has certainly been the state practice. It has certainly been the practice of Western Australia and it is the practice of Western Australia in its payments, less than generous though they may be, that they are applying in this particular case. They are still significantly, as I understand it, above legal aid rates.

As to the question of unfairness involved in all of this, of course it might well be thought to be unfair if legal aid funds were in fact being reduced by meeting these sorts of costs on a basis that is more generous than that available under legal aid, but the truth of the matter, of course, is that this comes out of totally separate pools and there is no question of competing for scarce funds in a single legal aid pool. If there was, there would be some more point, I think, to your question.

You have referred to people in similar circumstances receiving legal aid. I think the final point to be made is it is very hard to envisage anyone being caught up in similar circumstances to that which Dr Lawrence is here in a legal aid context because the situations are hardly comparable. Dr Lawrence find herself in this situation not as a result of any criminal or civil action being taken against her, the normal context, of course, in which legal aid issues arise. Rather, she finds herself being the subject of a manifestly politically inspired witch hunt which is made against her solely on the basis that she is a federal minister, and a highly effective, competent and honest one at that. That is the circumstance that makes her case very different from that which might be thought to arise in any legal aid situation anywhere in the country, and that adds further point, I think, to the wisdom of the position that has been taken on this matter from the outset by the government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for that answer, but I wonder if the minister could advise the Senate whether an ordinary citizen finding herself or himself before a commission inquiry of that type and seeking legal aid, because she or he is at risk, would be paid at legal aid rates or would be paid at the rate that, as the minister says, are commercial practice? Is he aware that there is a 20 per cent reduction of commercial practice rates for legal aid? Finally, would he be prepared to submit the invoices to an independent taxing authority to establish whether they are fair and reasonable, rather than the Government Solicitor?

—That supplementary question is really based on a false premise. There is no situation of which I am aware that a witness before a royal commission or someone the subject of a royal commission inquiry who might be thought to be at risk as a result of royal commission proceedings has been thrown on the mercy of legal aid or would need to have recourse to the legal aid commissions in various states or the Commonwealth, as the case may be. I am simply not aware of that situation arising.

PARA.TAB: What happens in those situations—and royal commission budgets are geared accordingly when they are set in train—is that people thought to be at risk, usually subject to some certification procedure by the royal commissioner, are entitled to access to the legal assistance funds made available as part of the funding of the costs of the particular royal commission in question and, when that happens, those funds are made payable in accordance with a formula with bears much more relationship to the fair and reasonable formula by reference to normal commercial standards than normal legal aid standards. We might lament, as we all do, the extraordinary cost of legal assistance in this country and the paucity of funds for legal aid, but the situations are not comparable. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook), to a question without notice asked by Senator Short this day, relating to taxation.

SPEECH.PARA: I today gave Senator Cook, on behalf of the government, the clearest possible invitation—and, indeed, I gave it to him yesterday also—to ease the concerns that millions of Australians have that Labor, if re-elected at the next election, will not increase taxes or introduce any new taxes. Yesterday and again today the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) refused to give that assurance to the Australian people. The best he could do was say that the government did not intend to introduce any new taxes.

PARA.TAB: That is not good enough. We have heard those statements time and time again in the past only to have them completely abrogated in terms of action when the election is out of the way. The government then raised taxes. The last election was perhaps the best example we have seen in the 12 years that this government has been in office of its duplicity on taxation policy and what it says before an election and what it does after an election.

During the last election campaign, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said in the clearest terms that the government would not introduce any new taxes after the election. He went to great pains to point out very rudely to those who questioned him on the proposed personal income tax cuts that had been promised before the election that they would be honoured because they were enshrined in l-a-w, law.

It subsequently emerged the very week after the election that the Prime Minister entered into discussions with the then Treasurer John Dawkins to dishonour the promise in relation to the second huge tranche of tax cuts—the $8 billion or so in tax cuts. That is precisely what happened. The government dishonoured that promise. As a result, the taxpayer expectation of a $5 1/2 billion tax cut to take effect from 1 January 1996 was thrown out the window as if it had never existed.

That was a promise that quite arguably won the election for Mr Keating in 1993. It was an election campaign based on lies and more lies. The Australian public is extremely concerned that the same is going to happen again next time. What happened after the 1993 election apart from the dishonouring of the major promise for personal income tax cuts? We had, contrary to all the promises before the election, a raft of sales tax increases across all items to which sales tax applies—that is, from motor vehicles down to many foodstuffs; all those items to which that discriminatory sales tax applies.

Not only that, though; the government then sought to impose sales tax for the first time on a whole raft of new items—the most notorious one of which was the builders hardware items. We saw the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology, representing the Treasurer, chastise me and chastise the coalition in the last two days for drawing attention to the fact that the government had broken its promises in that regard, by putting the imposition of the tax on, and chastise us for trying to keep them honest and adhering to their election promises.

The simple fact is that there is an insatiable demand by this government for increased expenditure. It is now going for another net $1 billion of expenditure over and above what was budgeted for. That coupled with a shortfall in its asset sales is going to make it absolutely certain that, after the next election, taxes would be increased if this government were returned. If this government had any sense of decency and propriety, it would get up now and state its tax policies and its tax intentions. The Australian people demand to know what the Labor Party's policy is in the area of taxation and all those areas that are of great concern to the Australian people. (Time expired)
Debate interrupted.
