Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to take note of the answer given by Senator Cook today. I do apologise to the Senate for being somewhat rowdy in my interjections during that answer. I must inform honourable senators that I mean it genuinely, because I do generally try to uphold the standards of this chamber, but there are times when one is confronted with—and I dare not use the word `hypocritical'—quite incredible propositions from this man who purports to be a minister of the Crown.

PARA.TAB: We have school children up in the gallery watching this debate today, and they probably watched the minister tell them how fantastic this nation is, and for young people that is most important. I say to those young people: just be very careful of what these ministers in this government say to you. They will tell you that the economy is all hunky-dory and their policies have delivered us this absolute nirvana of economic good news. They say, `Everything will be fantastic. Don't worry, you'll get a job.' That is what Minister Cook will tell you in his answers in this place and in his speeches around this nation.

I suggest to those students and perhaps their economics teacher at their school, if they have one, or another teacher, that they get any copy of the Economist magazine, available at newsstands and probably in most school libraries, which will show them in the back two or three pages the situation Australia is in in relation to the rest of the world. For example, you only need to look at what the minister says about our state of economic nirvana, how we have achieved this sustainable economic growth and how this will help everybody find jobs and find a sustainable economic future.

I refer all Australian citizens and honourable senators to the latest edition of the Economist where it looks at consumer price rises, known in the community as inflation—the increase in prices. In the last quarter Australia was ranked as having the highest inflation in the Western world, yet this minister and this government will have us believe that we are a low inflation sustainable growth nation. The reality is entirely the opposite.

In international terms we are not in the middle of the field in inflation rates, as we were during the previous coalition government under Malcolm Fraser and John Howard, where we were around middle ranking for most of the government and low inflation for much of it. We are the nation with the highest inflation in the Western world. That is an absolutely appalling statistic, yet we all tend to ignore it. Why do people ignore it? Because all of these government ministers, including the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), come in here and say that everything is okay and that we are a low inflation nation. They say that their great achievement of this second Keating government is to have low inflation.

In black and white and in the most respected international economic magazine we are actually the nation with the highest inflation. What does the Economist poll of international forecasters predict for Australia next year, 1996? Again, they are saying that we will have the second highest rate of inflation for 1996 and the highest rate for this year, but we will be amongst the highest inflation nations in the world.

We also have the highest interest rates in the world. We should look statistically at where home mortgage rates were. In his answer today Senator Cook was talking about how Australian citizens have to battle with high interest rates and how this government has helped to keep them down. The cold hard fact is that our real home interest rates—that is, when you get the base rate of interest, which you will see written in paint on the bank window trying to sell you a mortgage and have that deflated by people's expectations of inflation, that is, the price rises—under this government are actually five times higher than when they came into power in 1983.

The other sad thing about this is that the government will not show the people any policy solutions to the malaise they have caused to the Australian nation. They keep telling us that they are going to have this innovation statement, which I understand will be called `Innovating nation', already dubbed by Labor backbenchers as the bronze medal strategy of Senator Cook. Yet they will not tell us what is in it, they will not tell us how they will pay for it and they will not rule out new taxes to pay for it. This government is in turmoil. The Australian people deserve some policy answers. We deserve to see what policy solutions they have for the problems that they have very uniquely created.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by Senator Spindler this day, relating to the funding of legal action by the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) and the Western Australian Royal Commission on the Easton matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) made great play out of the fact that people appearing either as witnesses or as subjects of inquiry before royal commissions or similar tribunals do not as a rule get legal aid. That is not really the point. The point I was making is that, in principle, the same situation applies. Here we have a minister asking for assistance from public funds to cover her legal costs before a tribunal. On the other hand, we have hundreds and thousands of Australian citizens approaching public funds for assistance to cover their legal costs in court proceedings which affect them.

PARA.TAB: I put it to the minister that this is entirely analogous. The question that needs to be asked is: should the same principle apply, or do we say to a minister appearing before a tribunal that whatever it takes may go ahead? Was it really carte blanche? Did the government at any stage cap the fees that were to be charged, the costs that were to be incurred? Did the government at any stage participate in the decisions that were made in terms of the strategy of the court cases and challenges that the minister undertook which inevitably would result in higher costs to be met out of the public purse? The questions relate to government accountability. Has the government simply written a blank cheque? Is the government now asking the Senate to co-sign that blank cheque, or has the government put in provisos, protections or monitoring devices to ensure that the public purse is not taken to the cleaners?

There are two aspects of my supplementary question that the minister did not have time to answer, and I wonder whether he could do so now. One of them is whether the government is prepared to have the bills that are provided through Dr Lawrence taxed by an independent costing authority rather than the Australian Government Solicitor. Secondly, since the minister mentioned normal commercial practice, is he aware that in cases where legal aid is providing the funds it is normal practice for the fees to be reduced by 20 per cent before they are paid by legal aid?

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to canvass again the issues that were travelled in question time itself but, as to the further questions that Senator Spindler just then asked, I am of course aware that there is a cost reduction factor normally applied in legal aid payments. What that figure is from jurisdiction to jurisdiction I cannot confirm, but I have no doubt that there is a discount factor involved. But the point here is that, for reasons I have already spelt out, we do not regard that as a strictly comparable or relevant criterion to apply in making the calculation as to what payment ought to be made here. That has not been the practice in the past in the Commonwealth or at any state level in comparable situations.

PARA.TAB: As to the other question about whether we would be prepared to have the bills taxed by an independent costing authority, I will see whether the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) has anything more to say on that particular subject. My understanding is that the Australian Government Solicitor is quite familiar with the principles to be applied in the taxing of costs. We have a natural instinct to reduce the call upon Treasury funds, consolidated revenue, as much as is humanly possible.

It can be assumed that a rigorous approach would be adopted in the testing of the amounts that are put to us. It can also be assumed that there is plenty of expertise available to the Australian Government Solicitor through his internal staff to ensure that. Whether they take outside advice on some or all of these matters, I am not quite sure. If anything needs to be added to what I have said, I will make sure that Senator Spindler gets that answer. I do not believe it is done externally, but that may not be the case.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Bob Collins), to a question without notice asked by Senator Abetz this day, relating to a forest industry interim hardship scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators will recall that I asked a question concerning the forest industry interim hardship assistance scheme of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Bob Collins). The minister clearly was unable to provide me with an answer.

PARA.TAB: The confusion into which the forest industry was thrown occurred on 20 December last year. Indeed, yesterday was the 11-month anniversary of that statement by Mr Beddall. You will recall, Madam Deputy President, as will all other honourable senators, that as a result of that decision we had a huge blockade around this parliament.

Whilst the pressure was on, on 27 January this year the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) made an announcement that compensation would be paid to those family businesses and companies that suffered loss as a result of the government's decision. What the government promised through the Prime Minister was that the government would work in consultation with the industry, the unions and the states to assess the need.

On the best information to hand in my home state of Tasmania, the government has not consulted with the Forest Protection Society, the Tasmanian Logging Association or the Forest Industry Association of Tasmania. This is 11 months after the decision was made and 10 months after the promise was made by the Prime Minister.

These decisions that the government took had incurred family businesses and contractors in huge expenses, on the promise that the government would meet the costs. Contractors in my home state of Tasmania did not sack employees, on the strength of that promise made by the Prime Minister. They kept employees on, doing non-productive type work around depots and things of that nature, simply because they had such a good work force and on the promise that the government would compensate them. A lot of them drew on their overdraft facility to pay their employees.

Now, 10 or 11 months after the event, the government is putting down criteria such as: no reimbursement for the loss of net income. All they are going to do is pay for the extra cost incurred by having to move from one coupe to another coupe.

There is the question of lost time. You are about to start logging in one coupe and you have to move. A lot of those coupes are now being logged again because contractors were allowed back in when the government realised the foolishness of the decision made by the minister in this regard.

Nevertheless, a lot of people incurred substantial costs. The government is now saying, `No, only extra cost will be compensated.' There was the lack of income—income that would usually pay wages and pay off the overdrafts and the loans will not be compensated for.

One contractor, which is a family business in my home state, in the electorate of Franklin, has incurred a cost of $188,000. The government is now saying that there will be a limit of $30,000 per claim. They paid their workers, on the promise given by the Prime Minister that these costs would be reimbursed.

Further, we are now told that the costs incurred between 20 December 1994 and 27 January 1995 will be quarantined out of the equation. Minister Beddall made his announcement on 20 December. As a result, a lot of contractors had to relocate to other coupes and make alternative arrangements during that five-week period. The government now, so much later, says, `We won't compensate for that.'

There is a whole lot of other issues I could raise in relation to the appalling handling of this matter by this government. Time is against me. Let me simply say to the government that I will continually remind Minister Collins of the appalling way the families and industries in the forest area in Tasmania have been treated. I will continue to raise it in the Senate and at estimates committees to ensure that the families and the communities that rely on the forests are given appropriate compensation. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht), to a question without notice asked by Senator Colston this day, relating to the Australian Customs Service coastwatch contract for the Torres Strait.

SPEECH.PARA: This dorothy dix question was a very crudely designed attack on Mr Entsch. I am sorry that Senator Schacht did not pronounce his name properly. He is the next member for Leichhardt. He will replace Mr Dodd, universally known as Mr Dud, in Cairns.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask you to withdraw that.
—I withdraw.
—He is not one of the boys in suits?
—He is not one of the boys in suits. He is a migrant from the south. He is a Mexican.

PARA.TAB: I wish I had known this question was coming up because I would have briefed Mr Entsch properly and it would have really caused Senator Schacht some embarrassment. The question relates to the public concern in the aviation industry about the awarding of the latest Coastwatch contract. There are a lot of answers to be made. I have put a number of questions on notice over the last year and they have never been satisfactorily answered by the minister for customs, who is the minister responsible. This will probably end up as a Senate inquiry because there is such a degree of concern about the process that was followed in awarding the contract.

The answer that was given by Senator Schacht today related to the selection of an aircraft known as the Pilatus Britten-Norman Islander, which is universally recognised as being quite unsuitable for the task that Customs wishes to use it for. It is an aeroplane that is very slow, it has a very limited payload and it has a limited range. It is very hard to see out of—and it is being used for a visual task—and it is very noisy. It is not a habitable aircraft at all for long periods of crew duty.

Senator Schacht is arguing that, instead of a contract being let, they used an RFP this time—a request for proposal. When the request for proposal was issued there were certain base parameters laid down. Senator Schacht is arguing, in an attempt to justify this odd decision, that because it was an RFP and not a request for a tender, the government or Customs has the ability to then sit down with the tenderer and agree to different standards. What happened in this situation was that they agreed to standards that were considerably lower than they were asking for in their RFP.

We have a very inadequate aircraft, as I said. It is very slow. It is range-limited. It is an aircraft that is going to operate in the northern part of Australia. This time of the year onwards, for the next three or four months, it will be operating in the wet season. It cannot take off under instrument flight rules with the load that it can under the visual flight rules. I am advised that it has to fly for something like 90 minutes before it can go IFR in conditions which will apply for a large part of the year. Because of its limited capabilities, there are increases in the cost of operations.

There are allegations that the company sought to get an increase in the maximum all-up weight of the aircraft which was denied by CASA, or the Civil Aviation Authority as it was known at the time. The aircraft does not possess any effective airconditioning. Airconditioning in the tropics at low level, at which this aircraft operates, is not a luxury; it is essential for the minimisation of crew fatigue and for the electronic equipment that is on board. The humidity can be in the high 90s to 100 per cent.

It is alleged that, in relation to the Australian Customs Service, in May 1994 two officers came up from Canberra, chartered a Britten-Norman Islander in Cairns, flight tested it and found that it was completely unsuited to the Customs role. The request for the RFP that went out called for a minimal speed of 130 knots. This aircraft is flat out making 115 knots on the cruise. The concern in Queensland is that with an inadequate aircraft like that, and with the gateway to the north, which is vitally important from a migration point of view, as is the papaya fruit fly from a Customs and quarantine point of view, those standards are not going to be met. Nothing that Senator Schacht said today in any way dispelled the concerns that exist about how the aircraft was selected, how the contract was awarded and how the quarantine and customs duties are going to be dispensed in the north under this new contract.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was somewhat concerned by the answer the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction, Senator Schacht, gave to the dorothy dixer. Obviously Senator Schacht, feeling a little testy about his position, particularly in his role in Customs, chose to embark upon some sort of political attack.

PARA.TAB: He does not seem to understand—sitting down there in Adelaide at the other end of the country, along with the new owner of the Coastwatch contract—that people in Far North Queensland are very concerned about the openness of our northern borders to people, fruit flies and other substances coming in. It is a matter of major issue in Cairns, Far North Queensland and in fact in the whole of the electorate of Leichhardt. Senator Schacht mentioned Mr Warren Entsch, the Liberal candidate for Leichhardt. I am pleased that Senator Schacht did mention Mr Entsch, because it does demonstrate that Mr Entsch is on the ball and is reflecting very clearly the concerns of his constituents.

TALK.START.PARA: —He's a very good candidate.

—He is a very good candidate, as Senator Short says. This question and the answer demonstrate that Mr Entsch is in fact looking after his constituents—doing the job that should be being done by the current and very temporary member for Leichhardt (Mr Dodd). Obviously the current member for Leichhardt does not have much interest in these sorts of things, but Mr Entsch does.

PARA.TAB: Mr Entsch has been approached by quite a large number of people with concerns, some of which have been raised by my colleague Senator MacGibbon in his questions on notice some time ago. We are fortunate to have someone like Senator MacGibbon, who does understand the technicalities of these answers that are given. Senator Schacht, in response to Senator MacGibbon's questions, did try to go on with some technicalities. I am pleased that Senator MacGibbon has been able today to indicate just how poor those answers were and how lacking in any substance they really were.

There is a great concern about the way this contract has been let. Many honourable senators may remember that there was a lot of concern about the previous Coastwatch contract and the way that it had been let. One would have thought the government would have been extra careful this time in the way the contract was let.

There is a lot of concern about the type and the suitability of the aircraft being used. There is a lot of concern about the amount of equipment that is available to the Customs officers to do their surveillance. There is a lot of concern about the placement of those aircraft and the equipment. All of this has been quite clearly and properly raised by Mr Warren Entsch, the Liberal candidate for Leichhardt, in his role as having a concern for the people of Cairns and all parts of Far North Queensland.

Senator Schacht used the opportunity of a dorothy dix question simply to attack genuine Far North Queenslanders who are interested in their area. He carried on in his childish way and attacked me over an issue I raised here in the same vein many months ago—now an issue which really involves the bringing of drugs into this country through the Torres Strait. All Senator Schacht can do is laugh about it and laugh about the man with the red hat.

It was not so long after I raised these issues and concerns with Senator Schacht that indeed the Customs Service did have a major drug catch on the mainland in Bamaga, Far North Queensland. But it was not the surveillance of Customs that found that. As I said in the parliament the other day, some people in Mackay had reported that someone had come along and paid cash to buy an aircraft. It was as a result of that information that Customs eventually made the apprehension. But the concern was that the aircraft went all through the Torres Strait and on to the mainland of Australia, past all the surveillance safeguards we supposedly have up in the Torres Strait area and landed at Bamaga before it was apprehended following this tip-off. TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 October 1994 the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances reported to the Senate on its inquiry into the Legislative Instruments Bill 1994, referred to it by the Selection of Bills Committee. The committee endorsed the principles of the bill and supported its main principles. Nevertheless, the committee made 14 recommendations and suggestions which it considered would improve either the conceptual basis or the intended effect of the bill. The committee is pleased to recall that the government has now accepted 13 of the 14 suggestions, with the 14th to be subject to future review.

PARA.TAB: The government has now circulated proposed amendments of the bill, which is at present in committee stage in the Senate, to give effect to its acceptance of the committee's recommendations, to the government's response to the report on the bill of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs and to additional government initiatives. The committee has noted these amendments and wishes to draw to the attention of the Senate some aspects of the additional initiatives.

The present subclause 48(4) of the bill, which has no equivalent in the Acts Interpretation Act 1901, but which was included in the bill introduced into the Senate on 30 June 1994, provides for the House to defer disallowance of a legislative instrument for a period of up to six months to enable the instrument to be remade or amended to achieve a specified objective. The new proposed subclause 48(5), with new subclauses 48(6) and (7), is a consequent government initiative foreshadowed for the first time on 16 October 1995. I seek leave to incorporate the amendments in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The amendments read as follows—

(a)a House of the Parliament passes a resolution deferring for a period consideration of a motion to disallow an instrument or a provision of an instrument so as to enable the instrument or provision to be remade; and

(b)the rule-maker (after discussion with that House) makes a further legislative instrument (the `new instrument') either amending, or repealing and replacing, the original instrument so as to remake the original instrument or the provision of the original instrument that is the subject of the motion to disallow;

SPEECH.PARA: that House may discharge the motion to disallow.

PARA.TAB: "(6)In making the new instrument, the rule-maker is not required to enter into further consultation under Part 3.
"(7)When the new instrument is made:
(a)the rule-maker is required to lodge the instrument with the Principal Legislative Counsel for registration in accordance with the requirements of this act; and

(b)the explanatory statement to be lodged with the Principal Legislative Counsel concerning the instrument is not required to be accompanied by a statement of the kind referred to in subparagraph 32(2)(a)(vi) or (vii) but should contain instead a statement by the rule-maker to the effect that the instrument has been prepared to meet the requirements of the relevant House of the Parliament under this section; and
(c)the Principal Legislative Counsel must attend to the delivery to the Parliament of the instrument and of the related explanatory statement in accordance with the requirements of this Part."

TALK.START.PARA: —The Clerk of the Senate subsequently wrote to the committee on 31 October 1995 expressing concern about subclause 48(5). The main concerns of the clerk were, firstly, that there was no useful purpose to statutory provisions, such as these, which sought to recognise a parliamentary procedure which other statutory provisions and its own practices already allow. The clerk also suggested that the drafting of the amendments was vague and uncertain and, in any event, attempted to deal with concepts which could not be enacted satisfactorily. For instance, the government amendments provided for a rule-maker to hold discussions with a house, which is not possible. Also, the amendments could be used to prevent a senator from raising an issue. Debate on a motion could be avoided, which would be a dangerous precedent. Finally, the amendments do not advance parliamentary control over delegated legislation, because it is still the Senate which is the ultimate arbiter of whether an instrument is disallowed. I seek leave to incorporate the clerk's letter in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: 31 October 1995
Senator M Colston
Chair
Regulations and Ordinances Committee
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Colston

PARA.EMPHASIS: LEGISLATIVE INSTRUMENTS BILL 1994 REVISED SUBSTITUTE GOVERNMENT AMENDMENTS

SPEECH.PARA: Last week a set of government amendments to the Legislative Instruments Bill 1994, designated as revised substitute amendments, were circulated. One of the provisions in these amendments is of concern and I wish to draw it to the attention of the committee.

Amendment no. 78 would insert into clause 48 of the bill a new subclause (5). The Senate Department was asked to comment on this provision before the amendments were circulated, but subject to a very severe deadline for the printing and circulation of the amendments. In the short time available I suggested a change of wording to the new subclause 48(5), but was not able to undertake a proper analysis of the proposed provision. I indicated that I could see problems with it.

The proposed new subclause (5) provides that, if a disallowance motion is deferred by a House and a new instrument is made amending, repealing or replacing the instrument which is the subject of the disallowance motion, the House may discharge the disallowance motion.

The supplementary explanatory memorandum accompanying the amendments does not explain the rationale of this proposed provision, but merely restates its terms, as is usual with explanatory memoranda in recent times. It does not appear to arise from the recommendations of the committee or any previous consideration of the bill. Remarks made during the brief consultation to which I have referred suggested that the purpose of the proposed provision is to formalise the practice whereby a disallowance motion in the Senate is withdrawn when an amending instrument is made which overcomes the objection to the original instrument which was the subject of the disallowance motion.
There are several difficulties with the proposed provision.

In the first place, there would appear to be no particular reason for formalising the practice whereby disallowance motions are disposed of when a satisfactory amending instrument is made. The proposed provision merely indicates that the Senate may do that which other statutory provisions and its own practices already allow. Unless there is some useful purpose to be served by enacting statutory provisions which merely recognise parliamentary procedures, they should be avoided because they may unintentionally restrict those procedures.

Secondly, in attempting to give statutory expression to the practice which is particularly associated with the Regulations and Ordinances Committee, a practice which cannot be statutory codified, the proposed provision creates vagueness and uncertainty. It refers to the making of a new instrument after discussion with a House. It is not indicated how a rule-maker can discuss anything with a House; discussions can be held with the chair of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee when the committee has come to a view about an instrument, but discussions cannot be held with the Senate, particularly as the Senate may not have any agreed view about an instrument. The proposed provision does not say that the new instrument is to overcome the objections to the original instrument which are the basis of the disallowance motion, obviously because this concept cannot be statutory enacted, but the concept is absolutely central to the practice which the provision attempts to codify. Under that practice, disallowance motions are not withdrawn unless a new instrument or an undertaking overcomes the objections to the original instrument of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee or of the senator who has given the notice. The proposed subclause (5), in conjunction with proposed new subclause (6), would give a special status to an instrument which is not required by the terms of the provision to achieve the goal of overcoming the objection to the original instrument.

Thirdly, the proposed provision refers to a House discharging a motion to disallow the original instrument. The draft provision as originally shown to me provided for a House to "move a motion to rescind the motion to disallow". I pointed out that Houses do not move motions, that moving a motion is not the same as passing a motion, and that it is impossible to rescind a motion, as only a resolution, that is, a motion which has been passed, can be rescinded. I suggested the wording which now appears in the proposed subclause, but indicated that there was still a serious problem with it. The procedures of the Senate follow the principle that a notice of motion, before it has been moved and has become the property of the Senate, is entirely in the control of the senator who has given the notice. It is for that senator to determine whether the notice will be proceeded with. This is an important principle because, if the Senate could dispose of a senator's notice of motion before it is actually moved, this would open up enormous scope for a majority to interfere with a senator's right to initiate business; such a process could be used to prevent matters even being raised. The proposed provision would thus introduce a dangerous procedural novelty, a resolution by the Senate to discharge a notice of motion. If the subclause were enacted there would be a statutory provision for a procedure in relation to disallowance motions which is alien to the procedure applying to all other motions.

Fourthly, by attempting in this inadequate way to codify a parliamentary practice, the proposed subclause would open up an avenue for possible abuse. If a government thought that it had the support of a majority of the Senate to dispose of an embarrassing disallowance motion without being forced to debate or vote on it, a new instrument could be made without overcoming the objection to the original instrument which is the subject of a deferred disallowance motion, and a motion could then be moved to discharge the disallowance motion, thereby preventing the senator concerned from moving the motion, and avoiding the necessity of debating the motion and voting against it directly.

Fifthly, having unnecessarily created these difficulties, the proposed provision would not advance parliamentary control over delegated legislation in the slightest degree. If a notice of motion for disallowance has reached the time for determination, whether or not it is deferred under the proposed provisions of clause 48, the Senate must decide whether to proceed with the disallowance of the instrument, either by agreeing to the motion or by allowing the statutory period to expire, or to allow the withdrawal of the notice of motion. In making that decision the Senate may have regard to either ministerial undertakings in relation to the instrument in question or a new instrument which may have been made. In making its decision and in having regard to those matters, the Senate would not be assisted in any way by the proposed new subclause (5).
I therefore suggest that the proposed new subclause should not be agreed to.
If the committee so wishes I would be pleased to elaborate on or clarify this submission.
Yours sincerely
(Harry Evans)

TALK.START.PARA: —On receipt of this letter the chairman convened a special meeting of the committee for the next sitting day, 13 November 1995. The Clerk of the Senate, Mr Richard Morgan and Ms Helen Towney, both from the Civil Law Division of the Attorney-General's Department, also attended the meeting. The committee is grateful for their assistance.

PARA.TAB: The committee concluded that, while it would not oppose the amendments, it was desirable for them to be amended in light of the difficulties noted by the clerk and discussed at the special meeting. This would involve deletion of all references to a house in proposed new subclause 48(5), which would instead merely refer to the existing practice, most often associated with the committee, where a notice of disallowance has been given in respect of an instrument and where a new instrument is made to overcome parliamentary concerns about the original instrument.

The committee also concluded that drafting changes were necessary to proposed new subclauses 48(6) and (7), which provide that a rule-maker is not required to enter into further consultation about a new instrument although, with several exceptions, the new instrument will be subject to the other provisions of the bill. Here also the committee concluded that an inappropriate reference to a house should be removed, while more safeguards for the public should be included. These safeguards were to make it clear that, while further consultation was not mandatory for new instruments, it was to be encouraged where appropriate that the explanatory statement should indicate whether such consultation had taken place and, if so, the nature of the consultation.

The result of the suggested changes to the government amendments is that consultation procedures for instruments made to overcome parliamentary concerns about earlier instruments will be less restrictive than the far from onerous consultation requirements for other instruments. These new consultation procedures would, however, include appropriate safeguards for the public which are lacking in the present government amendments.

Accordingly, in the absence of similar government amendments when the bill comes before the Senate, I will, on behalf of the committee, move amendments to the bill to this effect. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the proposed amendments suggested by the committee.
Leave granted.
The proposed amendments read as follows—

"(5) Subsections (6) and (7) apply to an instrument (the `new instrument') which repeals, replaces or amends an instrument or a provision of an instrument (the `original instrument/provision') when:

PARA.TAB: (a)the new instrument is intended to overcome parliamentary concerns about the original instrument/provision; and
(b)a notice of motion has been given to disallow the original instrument/provision.

SPEECH.PARA: "(6) In making the new instrument, the rule-maker is not required to, but may if appropriate, enter into further consultation under Part 3.

PARA.TAB: (a)the rule-maker is required to lodge the instrument with the Principal Legislative Counsel for registration in accordance with the requirements of this act; and

(b)the explanatory statement concerning the instrument lodged with the Principal Legislative Counsel is not required to be accompanied by a statement of the kind referred to in subparagraph 32(2)(a)(vi) or (vii), but must contain:

TAB.TAB: (i)a statement by the rule-maker to the effect that the instrument has been prepared under this section to overcome parliamentary concerns about the original instrument/provision; and
(ii)a statement indicating whether consultation has occurred in relation to the instrument and, if so, the nature of the consultation; and

PARA.TAB: (c)the Principal Legislative Counsel must attend to the delivery to the Parliament of the instrument and of the related explanatory statement in accordance with the requirements of this Part."

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the President and in accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the Auditor-General's report No. 9 of 1995-96: Performance audit—Teleservice Centres—Department of Social Security.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This was a good idea, the teleservice centres. It meant that people—I think the new word is `clients'—could ring up the Department of Social Security and seek to have their problems resolved, where they could, over the phone.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, it does not seem to have worked as well as it should have. For example, the cost was supposed to be $40 million a year in 1992-93 prices. In fact, it has blown out by 40 per cent to $56 million. It does not provide anything like the service that it was supposed to provide. It is grossly inadequate. The Auditor-General has noted:

SPEECH.PARA: Teleservice operations have had difficulty in meeting performance standards relating to the key client service objectives set for the initiative.

That is a polite Auditor-General's remark for saying it has not worked properly. Not only has not it worked properly; it has cost far more than it should have and the Department of Social Security has to do something about it. The audit finding was that:
. many of the difficulties faced by the Teleservice Centres

PARA.TAB: could have been alleviated, or largely overcome, by better
planning, project management and methods used in implementation;

SPEECH.PARA: It continues:
. the nature and levels of resourcing and work practices do not sufficiently support operations;
.service performance targets have consequently not been met;
.initiatives can and have been identified to improve client service. These include:

PARA.TAB: -more clearly establishing which elements of client service are most important to the client;
-determining a more appropriate range and level of service targets;
-a more systematic approach to quality assurance control; and
-improving access to the service (e.g. a wider range of operating hours;

SPEECH.PARA: It adds:
.Teleservice Centres can be better integrated into DSS operations for better overall performance.
The Audit Office says:
DSS has largely accepted the ANAO recommendations . . . As a result, management of the Teleservice function has improved.
I must say some of the figures quoted in the audit report do not suggest they have improved at all. They seem to suggest, in fact, that some of the services are getting worse. The report continues:

However, the ANAO considers that the extent of the problems are such that more fundamental changes along the lines outlined in this report should be considered by DSS management to deliver administratively effective and efficient Teleservice operations.
DSS has indicated that many of the fundamental changes required are constrained by the APS industrial relations and budgeting environment.
The report continues:

While acknowledging such difficulties, the ANAO suggests that management has to set priorities and achieve the balance necessary between resourcing and other operational concerns and he achievement of program objectives, of which quality client service delivery is acknowledged to be an important element.
The report continues:
To date, performance has fallen short of the standards and expectations set initially with respect to both client service and operating efficiencies.
The report concludes:

Difficulties with resourcing models, staffing arrangements, client service, quality control and assurance, integration and configuration have continued to hamper Teleservice operations. Action in train and proposed by DSS should do much to overcome such difficulties.

Well, it is a fairly damning report, as is evident from that summary. However, when you go to the report in detail, you find that these problems have resulted in a degree of frustration with the teleservice centre operations amongst people who use them, that is, what is now called the DSS client base. There has been disaffection with teleservice centre operations within the Department of Social Security regional office network itself and insufficient priority has been given to resolving the fundamental problems facing teleservice centre operations. A good deal of frustration and pressure is being felt by teleservice centre operators, supervisors and management. That is bad enough. The service, in other words, is grossly inadequate.

PARA.TAB: On the question of the service being grossly inadequate, a table on page 35 of the report reveals the target service levels set by the Department of Social Security for the percentage of calls answered by an operator within one minute of the client making the call. The original target set by the department was that 98 per cent of calls were going to be answered within one minute. It became obvious that they would never reach that sort of target so they changed it to 85 per cent, and it remains at 85 per cent. That is just ludicrous, because not one teleservice centre has met anything like that 85 per cent target.

In Sydney, for example, only 23 per cent of calls were answered within one minute. That is all—only 23 per cent. That means that 77 per cent of calls involved people hanging on for longer than one minute. We do not know how much longer than one minute because they have not measured how long people have to hang on before they receive attention.

The Sydney situation is continually worsening. When the program started in July-December 1993—that is when 98 per cent was the target—only 52 per cent of calls were answered within one minute. In January-June 1994 it deteriorated from 52 per cent to 32 per cent. In July-December 1994 it worsened to 31 per cent. In the later six months to June this year it has fallen to 23 per cent. A constant worsening of the situation; a constantly worse service being provided.

Sydney is not the only example. There are some other areas where the service is pretty terrible too. In Brisbane, which is separated into A and B centres, the percentage of calls being answered within one minute is now down to 27 per cent for Brisbane A and 29 per cent for Brisbane B. Most other centres are well under half of their target level of 85 per cent. The current operational arrangements for teleservice centres, as the Auditor-General says, have failed to deliver on this aspect of access.

On top of that, not only does it take so long to answer the calls, the hours in which the services are available are grossly inadequate in comparison with what the target initially was. Extended hours of access were intended when the service was launched, as reflected in the minister's statement of March 1992, which envisaged teleservice centres offering extended service to Social Security clients through the transfer of calls between the teleservice centres in different time zones. There were to be wider hours of access, either through call shedding or extended operational hours, which were, according to the minister, to be of particular benefit to those clients with families, clients working or seeking work and those who are full-time carers enabling them to obtain access at more convenient times.

But it just has not happened. Current operational arrangements for teleservice centres have failed to deliver on this aspect of access. Teleservice centres operate from Monday to Friday only between 8.30 a.m. and 4.30 p.m.—essentially, the traditional opening times for the existing regional office network—and there is no call shedding between teleservice centres.

So here we have an inadequate service and a much more expensive service. As I said, it went up by 40 per cent from the forecast of $40 million to $56 million. This increase in running costs occurred even though current call volumes were close to those estimated in 1992 and they did not have the expenses of having extended hours. Those components of costs that have contributed most to the higher ongoing resourcing requirements for teleservice operations have been labour costs and call costs. Wage costs have remained high as a result of the inability to achieve the staffing economies expected from teleservice centres. There is an immense amount of work to be done yet to make this either an efficient or an effective service.

The reasons behind these amendments in the committee stage are as follows. Amendment No. 1 would make it clear that it is the parliament's intention that Sydney and Sydney West airports should not be leased until the aircraft noise burden is spread more equitably. Amendment No. 2 would remove Sydney airport and Sydney West airport from the list of core regulated airports in clause 7 of the Airports Bill.

PARA.TAB: The bill is structured so the government can add additional airports to the list of core regulated airports by regulation. So coalition amendment No. 3 would prevent the government from adding Sydney airport and Sydney West airport to the list by regulation. Coalition amendment No. 3 makes it clear that new airports can only be added to the list subject to a new subsection 7(2).

Coalition amendment No. 4 would enact the first of our two conditions that I set out in my speech in the second reading debate yesterday. It would add a new subsection 7(2) which would prevent the government from leasing Sydney and Sydney West airports unless it first developed a strategy for increasing the use of the east-west runway. The strategy would have to be endorsed by parliament. Amendment No. 5 is simply a machinery measure.

The amendments to the Airports (Transitional) Bill are similar to the amendments to the Airports Bill. Amendment No. 1 would make it clear that it is parliament's intention that Sydney and Sydney West airports should not be leased until the aircraft noise burden is spread more equitably. Amendment No. 2 would remove Sydney and Sydney West from the list of leaseable airports in section 19 of the bill. The section currently allows the government to add airports to the list of leaseable airports by regulation.

Amendments Nos 4 and 5 would prevent the government from putting Sydney and Sydney West back onto the list by regulation unless it first developed a strategy for increasing the use of the east-west runway. Finally, coalition amendment No. 3 would add Adelaide airport to the list of leaseable airports, thus carrying out the second condition that I raised in my speech in the second reading debate.

It is in the government's hands as to whether these bills are passed. I think the Democrats and the Greens have made it quite clear they do not believe in privatisation of any sort, so they do not intend to support these bills. We have moved two sets of amendments as a result of government policy decisions. These decisions had nothing to do with safety at the time, which has been thrown around this place ad nauseam. The two major policy decisions of this government were, first of all, to close the east-west runway and then to narrow the flight corridors north and south of the airport. This has been made very clear to me in my capacity on the select committee that is looking at Sydney airport.

The government's policy decision to narrow the corridors has meant that they, the government, have determined the flight corridors, the flight paths. I would have thought of that as being an extremely silly thing, a stupid thing. Under this government 13 months ago we had two runways at Sydney, both of which were active. On 4 November 1994, the new runway was completed. It was opened ahead of time—again, resulting from a policy decision by Minister Brereton. No-one is too sure as to why that was done, because the control tower was not operational. But the effect of that was to send something like double or triple the number of aircraft north of the airport.

The effect of that, of course, was that we had blockades led, I might say, by Labor Party stalwarts like Barry Cotter, the Mayor of Marrickville, in what Senator Forshaw in his speech on the second reading referred to as the over-Labor electorates. I might say that I was somewhat amazed by that comment from Senator Forshaw. He was sort of congratulating the government because they had directed aircraft over Labor-run electorates, and he spoke of Sydney, Grayndler and Lowe.

The interesting thing about that is that it just shows the utter disregard by this Labor government for constituents in electorates it does not think it can lose—and did not think it could lose. We had ministers in the other place saying that the reason we were requesting this was for a handful of votes in the seat of Bennelong. Anyone knows darn well that the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, is not going to lose his seat in Bennelong under any circumstances; no way in the world is that going to happen.

So here we have the curious situation of the coalition being concerned about the fact that people, the so-called `true believers', have been let down and abused by their own party which they have supported for many years. So it is a curious situation in that here it is the coalition—and this, I suppose, reflects the broad nature of the coalition: a party which is not subject to a particular single interest vested group, in the way in which the Labor Party is—which is prepared to show some concern for the people on whom one of the great disasters of Sydney has been inflicted.

To recapitulate, there are good reasons as to why our amendments should be supported by the government. The bottom line is that this government would prefer to rely on the expert advice that it has received, and continues to receive, from the safety and aviation authorities in this country rather than rely on the advice of the Leader of the Opposition in determining what is the most safe and efficient operation for an airport. I know what Senator Parer's corporate credentials are and I know the philosophical positions he has previously taken in this chamber in relation to many of these issues. I know that Senator Parer knows that to attempt to link the fundamental question of leasing airports in Australia to the operation of the east-west runway at Sydney or any other airport is a spurious argument indeed.

The government's leasing strategy, which involves the simultaneous sale of the four major airports with cross-ownership restrictions on Sydney and Brisbane as well as Sydney and Melbourne, is absolutely vital to the airport proposal. Acceptance of the opposition's amendments to exclude Sydney and Sydney West would destroy this strategy, cut the level of bidder interest in each of the major airports and significantly reduce budget revenues.

As the FAC's most valuable and attractive asset, Sydney is the key element in a leasing strategy which reflects expert financial and commercial advice to the government. With the cross-ownership restrictions in place, bidders will not want to bid for other airports, acquisition of which could restrict their ability to bid for Sydney. They would be unable to settle their bidding strategy for the major airports if Sydney were excluded. The exclusion of Sydney and Sydney West will simply sabotage the sale process and unnecessarily delay the vital development of Sydney West. That is precisely the end that the opposition is aiming to achieve.

The government has carefully negotiated with the South Australian government vital runway upgrade works at Adelaide airport as part of its commitment to transport developments in South Australia. The Adelaide community has been pushing for the extension of that runway for many years. The opposition amendments are simply a stunt to divert attention from the priority which should be given to that runway development. The opposition's amendments jeopardise plans for improvements to Adelaide airport.

The decision to include only the four largest airports and not Adelaide in the first phase of the sale reflects the outcome of the market testing program. That program showed that the focus of investor interest was on the three largest east coast airports and Perth. Frankly, I do not think that will come as a major surprise to anybody. The preference of most potential investors is to secure one of these airports before entertaining a bid for airports such as Adelaide. The government also took account of commercial advice that offering airports such as Adelaide in the first phase could result in a paucity of investor interest in those airports when the focus of investors would be on bidding for the majors. This would not serve South Australia's regional interests well.

Senator Bourne has taken the view in this debate—a view with which I respectfully disagree with—that the leasing of the airports will automatically lead to worse environmental outcomes due to unfettered private airport development. The Airports Bill strengthens environmental protection from airport operators. At the outset, it should be made clear that the development of airport regulatory arrangements post leasing does not affect the operation of existing legislation and regulations which cover curfews, runway operations, flight path and noise issues and the acquisition and insulation programs for housing.

Under the bills, as is currently the case, where proposed developments would have a significant environmental impact, the requirement for environmental impact assessments will apply to the airport lessees. The Commonwealth Environmental Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act will continue to apply to federal airport developments. However, in addition to these requirements, airport lessees will, under the Airports Bill, be required to develop and implement environmental strategies.

These strategies will include specific measures to be carried out by lessees for preventing, controlling or reducing environmental impacts. The bill requires lessees to take all reasonable steps to comply with environmental strategies and provides ministerial powers to seek injunctions to this effect. These new environmental provisions will help achieve progressive and sustainable improvements in the environmental outcomes at airports post leasing.

I make the point to Senator Parer that there is no logical connection, and he knows it, between the leasing of airports in Australia and the use of runways at each or any one of those airports. The two things are completely separate. This is simply a stunt and a political strategy to subvert these sales and a bit of grandstanding in Sydney to highlight this wonderful about face that the coalition has engaged in on the third runway.

I will conclude by responding briefly to a point raised by the Leader of the Democrats, Senator Kernot, who questioned the importance of the passage of this legislation at this time. The leasing of airports is a vital element of the government's future budgetary objectives which it will seek to protect. There is still a great deal to be done in the development of regulations which contain the fine detail to major interested parties, including state, territory and local governments. As I mentioned earlier today, that may well be an outcome. Delays to the bills will only create unnecessary uncertainty for all of the parties concerned.

The Airports Bill and the Airports (Transitional) Bill, backed by pricing and quality of service oversight by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission, are an essential part of the establishment of an appropriate framework for the leasing and regulation of federal airports. The bill provides for the separation of the operation of the airports from government regulation of airports in the public interest. I say again to Senator Bourne that leasing of the airports does not impact on existing environmental legislation, regulations or arrangements and airport lessees will not be able to avoid their environmental obligations.
