SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating two bills cognately: the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1995 and the Taxation Laws Amendment (FBT Cost of Compliance) Bill 1995. Originally these bills were to be debated separately. However, given the time now available for debate in this place, it is necessary to take these bills together and, in so doing, assist the government out of its legislative logjam.

PARA.TAB: Whilst I was intending to make extensive comments on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3), I now find it necessary to limit my remarks. To this end I simply note that the bill has eight major features, none of which is likely to ignite the imagination of the broad community. The revenue implications of the individual items in this bill are not large. Notwithstanding the significance of these measures for the government's taxation system, many of these measures are important.

As time is limited today, I would like to highlight just one of these measures. The government's moves to reduce the PAYE early remitter threshold from $5 million to $1 million in annual remittances is anticipated to increase the government's revenue this year, and this year alone, by some $275 million. As a result of this amendment, group employers who have annual PAYE remittances in excess of $1 million per year will be required to remit instalment deductions in the first 14 days of the month to the Commissioner of Taxation by the 21st day of the month. Deductions made in the balance of the month must be paid for by the seventh day of the following month.

Currently, employers with annual remittances below $5 million remit tax instalments for a month in a single payment on the seventh day of the following month. This change will take effect in respect of instalments deducted on or after 1 December 1995. For employers whose PAYE remittances are between $5 million and $1 million per annum there will be an additional cost in complying with these changes, as they will need to adjust their operations to take account of the fact that they will now be early remitters.

It is true that the additional cost will probably be absorbed by all employers and will be a one-off cost. Nevertheless, it is worth asking: why has the government introduced this measure if it will merely increase compliance costs, will have no more than a one-year effect and only brings forward revenue which the government will otherwise gain in the course of time?

Naturally, the answer to the question lies in the priorities of the Labor government. At a time when Australia has over 700,000 of its people on the unemployment queues, why does the government increase costs for the businesses which must ultimately provide many of these people with work? Sadly, it is because this Labor government has introduced this petty measure for the sole and wholly unsatisfactory reason that it has failed the test of economic management.

It wanted in May of this year to have the Australian people believe that it could construct a budget surplus. This measure is solely about cooking the books. Sadly for the government and for Australia, the Labor Party's failure to run this country's affairs has been long recognised. For within hours of the budget in May, the truth of that budget was revealed. The truth of the budget balance was obvious: there was no surplus, as generally understood. The budget balance was constructed without foundation and was premised on faulty fiscal materials.

Given that the surplus has long ago evaporated, now might be a reasonable time for the government to admit that this specific measure is for balance sheet purposes only, concede it will have no net economic benefit to our nation and withdraw the provision. I recognise that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Sherry), who is at the table, does not have the authority to act on this measure today. However, I ask him to explain to the Australian people, in his response to this debate, how this measure will improve economic efficiency, how it might increase employment, how it will create the environment for a sustained reduction in interest rates, or how it will improve our taxation system.

I fear that the measure is already set in concrete and that, in this government, once the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has made his mind up, Labor's mind is made up. The coalition will not oppose the measure, as it relates to the administration of the taxation system and not to the principles underlying it. It is, however, a measure of madness and a measure of this government's madness. As I stated earlier, I do not intend to concentrate on this bill at length. The coalition will not oppose the provisions of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3).

I turn now to the Taxation Laws Amendment (FBT Cost of Compliance) Bill 1995. This is a very important bill for this parliament, as it represents one of the few times that this Labor government has actually admitted that it could get things wrong. The bill amends the Income Tax Assessment Act and the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act in order to implement the results of a review of FBT compliance costs.

Taxation compliance costs refer to those costs which a taxpayer encounters in complying with the law—the law as created by this government and enacted in this parliament. Compliance costs in our taxation system make the system less efficient. Some may say they make the system positively defective.

Compliance costs for taxpayers was a matter addressed by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts during its inquiry into the Australian Taxation Office between 1991 and 1993. The committee's report No. 326 summarises the issue neatly and I would like to quote from it. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: To date, it has not been a requirement that the cost of compliance be calculated or estimated prior to a legislative change being enacted.
As the law has been adjusted on a piecemeal basis, compliance costs have not been viewed as a necessary concern for the revenue.
To the extent that the Commonwealth does not pay tax, compliance costs have not been a major consideration in making legislative change.
However, compliance costs do affect the capacity of business to function profitably.
Moreover, the greater the cost of compliance the greater the incentive for taxpayers not to comply.
Compliance costs can therefore be considered to include the additional costs arising from obscure, complex or uncertain laws.

While it is difficult to calculate the cost of complying to any given law for any given taxpayer, it is reasonable to consider compliance costs as a factor in the efficiency of an economy—though not necessarily one which is of itself critical.

I thoroughly support these comments. It was because of concern that the costs of the FBT system had become both administratively defective and economically destructive that the government instigated a review of its operations.

PARA.TAB: Since the inception of the system, the government has been warned that there would be significant costs in administering the FBT legislation. The government was told that the costs of the system would substantially reduce its economic efficiency.

It was demonstrated to the government that while FBT was, in the language of taxation economics, equitable, it was also administratively complex and therefore costly to administer and operate. Nevertheless, this government has relied upon the FBT because of its heavy reliance on revenue to fund its extravagant expenditure priorities.

The review of FBT compliance costs was long overdue. Nevertheless, the commitment of this government to reducing compliance costs can only be judged by what it has included in this legislation. On that score, we look to the words of the Treasurer (Mr Willis) during his announcement of the results of the costs review in February 1995.

In releasing the review's finding, the Treasurer announced that the government would increase the rate of tax payable on car fringe benefits. The end result in this instance is quite remarkable. At the end of the day, when this legislation is passed, it will result in the government actually raising more revenue from the FBT.

In essence, the Labor Party has recognised that the costs of complying with the FBT legislation are too great. But instead of finding fundamental ways of reducing compliance costs, it has restructured the system in a manner that maintains its revenue base. The government's priorities in this legislation are clear. The government is saying to the Australian people: `Yes, the law is too complicated; yes, the law imposes too great a cost on individuals and businesses; yes, we will restructure some components of the law. But, no, we will not, cannot and shall not alter the taxation system if it means less revenue for government.'

Australians should understand now, more clearly than ever, that the Labor Party views the taxation system merely as the means by which revenue is raised for expenditure by government. When the Labor Party talks tax, it is talking about how to take more money from people's pockets. It is not talking about what is right or equitable.

What was the point of the compliance costs review if the outcome was to raise more revenue from taxpayers? Several representatives of the business and professional communities have expressed their opinion on this matter. Mr Bob Jeffery, the National President of the Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants, has said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the so-called review of FBT has turned out to be just a thinly veiled exercise to appease genuine business concerns while still slugging business to raise the same amount of money.
The Executive Director of the Corporate Tax Association, Mr Bob Bryant, has stated:
What he—
the Treasurer—
handed down in our view was not a serious attempt to come to grips with the inadequacies of the FBT regime. He has really let us down.

The coalition agrees with these views. We believe this legislation is fundamentally flawed in principle and is therefore of dubious value. After so much effort and so much discussion, the fact that there is so much dissatisfaction with this legislation leads to the conclusion that the government really has little, if any, interest in reforming the law to reduce the costs of compliance.

PARA.TAB: I would now like to turn briefly to a number of the substantive measures of this bill. Schedule 1 of the bill amends the FBT Assessment Act in respect of meal entertainment. These amendments highlight the bureaucracy of the FBT system. The methods are a 50-50 split and a 12-week register. Many employers who adopt the 50-50 split method may actually pay more FBT than if they were to base their calculations on actual expenditure.

The Senate Economics Legislation Committee heard evidence on this proposed amendment. While the coalition recognises the arguments that have been made in respect of the efficacy of the amendments, it is inclined to support this change. Nevertheless, as the minority report of the committee makes clear, it would be preferable either to have a three-way split rather than the proposed 50-50 split or to return to the original non-deductible, non-FBT regime.

Schedule 2 of the bill was to have introduced some certainty in relation to living away from home allowances. I understand that the government has now proposed to drop these reforms. While the coalition welcomes the government's belated decision—almost a near death conversion—it is appropriate to recognise just what this government was proposing to do and what we could reasonably expect it to do were it to be returned at the next election.

The government had intended that an allowance would be a living away from home allowance fringe benefit only where the total period for which the employee had lived, or was required to live, away from his or her home was less than 12 months, where Australian residents were posted within Australia, or two years if the employee were posted to a remote location. The maximum residence period for employees working in Australia on temporary work permits and Australian residents posted overseas was four years. These changes would have been discriminatory and would have increased compliance costs.

This matter was the subject of significant investigation by the Senate Economics Legislation Committee, and it was thoroughly analysed and criticised in the minority report of that committee. The government has since had time to reflect upon the wisdom and astuteness of the views contained in that committee's minority report.

Much as I welcome the government's decision to omit schedule 2, I commend and congratulate the members who put their signatures to the minority report. In particular, I believe that the strength and wisdom of the words penned by my colleague Senator Watson should further enhance his standing in this place as a practical scholar of taxation law.

The coalition will support the government's amendment. I note, however, that the explanatory memorandum does not explain why, after so arrogantly and persistently defending the changes, the government has made this move. I look forward to the minister's explanation.

Schedule 3 of the bill deals with the FBT on car parking benefits. Under these amendments, FBT will no longer apply to car parking benefits unless a commercial station within a one-kilometre radius of employer provided car parking facilities charges at least $5 per day on the first day of the FBT year. The $5 threshold, without indexation, may result in the exemption for car parking in regional centres being short-lived. Accordingly, while the coalition will be supporting this measure, it will be moving an amendment to index the $5 figure in line with CPI rises.

Under the bill, employers are given two ways to calculate the total taxable value of car parking benefits provided in a year. Under the first of these, the statutory formula method, the taxable value for each space is calculated by multiplying a statutory number of days—240—by the daily rate. Unfortunately, in setting the statutory number of days at 240, the government has ignored public holidays. The coalition will be moving an amendment to reduce the statutory number of days to 228 to take account of 12 national public holidays.

The government may claim that it is inappropriate to take holidays into account because the car park may be used by a third party, another employee, on these days. However, all the coalition amendment seeks to do is remove national public holidays from the calculation. It assumes that on these days no worker will use the car park. I look forward to hearing the minister's response on this matter in the committee stage.

The bill also finally restores some sense to the FBT rules by excluding a number of items that should never have had the FBT applied to them as they do not have the characteristic of a fringe benefit. Unfortunately, a number of items are not included in the list of exempt items. Why this should be so is not clear.

The final measure I wish to touch on today relates to taxi travel provided to employees for travel directly between work and home between 8 p.m. and 6 a.m. and taxi travel provided for sick or injured employees to travel from work to their usual place of residence. There is a great deal of merit in these proposals. However, the limits the government has placed on the exemption just do not reflect reality. The coalition will be moving an amendment to modify the hours of exemption, such that they will be between 7 p.m. and 7 a.m. These hours not only reflect commercial reality but also reflect more closely the hours of daylight in the majority of Australia for most of the year.

In summary, the coalition believes that there remains an urgent need to review the fundamentals of the FBT legislation to ensure that the policy works in practice. We accept the economic justification for the tax. However, its value depends critically on how it is administered, and presently it is not, in its totality, administered efficiently.

The coalition is committed to reform of the FBT. I cannot bring myself to honestly say to the Australian people that what we have here today is reform. It is a move in the right direction, but it is not reform. Only a coalition government will act to reform the FBT legislation. Only the coalition can and will provide a taxation system that is equitable, just and efficient to administer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats think the Taxation Laws Amendment (FBT Cost of Compliance) Bill 1995 is the damp squib of finality—the end of a process which started with a promise to make the incomprehensible FBT system more user friendly. It is true that the review of compliance cost was announced in the 1994 budget. Almost immediately though, I think the review went off the rails because the government announced that the outcome had to be revenue neutral.

PARA.TAB: This overriding policy objective meant that it would be almost impossible to reverse the trend of the fringe benefits tax encroaching more and more onto items which it should never have been applied to. It is an interesting strategy from the government, but it is one that they have adopted and are sticking to. The strategy basically is, `We don't want to have any discussion about how to broaden the revenue base. We don't want to talk about the fairest ways of raising revenue. What we will do is just apply existing taxes and test them against every nook and cranny we can find.' I suppose that, electorally, that is a bit more palatable, because the government can say, `This isn't a new tax. This is an existing tax, and we are just widening its application.' I understand the politics of that, but it really has led to some ludicrous situations.

Let me restate for the record that, when we had the first fringe benefits tax debates in this place—and they were very divisive—the Democrats supported them. We still do. The existence of the fringe benefits tax legislation has had the effect of closing a whole string of loopholes. It has been a very effective revenue collector, adding this year in gross terms about $2.8 billion to the revenue. The opposition is on the record now as saying that they are not going to go backwards and get rid of the fringe benefits tax.

The fringe benefits tax creates massive compliance costs for business. I know the government is aware of that and that this is its response. However, a study by the Australian Tax Research Foundation has found that the smaller the business the more onerous the FBT liability. We are a bit disappointed to have to say that this final result which we are debating at the moment does not go far enough in our view.

While the package provides for more use of statutory formulas, the restrictions on using these formulas remain quite high. The Democrats think more use could be made of statutory formulas and statutory amounts to reduce compliance costs. Several businesses over the past year have told us—although I guess when it comes to the test they might change their mind—that they would be prepared to pay more fringe benefits tax if compliance costs were dramatically reduced. I think we should be about providing more options to business. Surely it is not just a lack of imagination on the part of the government and the tax office that is precluding reforms in that direction.

I think the application of an existing tax to every existing nook and cranny has led to the income tax system being stretched to the absolute extreme of crackdowns on small taxpayers so that two-thirds of people audited on their returns have been found to have made mistakes. We have had fringe benefits tax extended to inappropriate things such as employee share plans, late night taxis and mobile phones. We had the really absurd situation of four people sitting down to a business lunch being subject to four different tax formulas. This has led to confusion and I suppose a certain amount of frustration and anger across the business community, as more attempts have been made to eke out every possible dollar.

That said, this legislation contains a few welcome reforms. It is made cost neutral by the $121 million in extra taxes on motor vehicles—still the biggest single contributor to fringe benefits tax collections. The bill will exempt from fringe benefits tax a range of products primarily used for business. This is a good thing. It includes protective clothing, calculators, tools of trade, computers and mobile phones. The bill exempts late night taxi travel. It reduces the number of declarations required to be made by employers—although we think this concession might yet prove to be of dubious value. The key changes are to entertainment and car parking expenses. On entertainment, the bill provides a further two options for determining the taxable benefit: a statutory 50 cent of cost method and a 12-week register method. On car parking, fringe benefits tax will be restricted to employers within one kilometre of commercial parking stations charging $5 or more. This avoids the ludicrous situation of parking metres resulting in fringe benefits tax liabilities for nearby employers. It is good to see that the bill will give employers several options on how to calculate their benefits.

The bill also proposes to change the taxation of living away from home allowances. It has emerged in evidence to the Senate committee that the result of these changes would be to increase revenue and compliance costs rather than reduce them. I am glad that the government has since dropped those provisions from this bill.

I turn briefly to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1995. As others have said, it contains mostly uncontroversial provisions. The key provisions include changes to the taxation of the income of controlled foreign companies; changes to dividend franking rules to exclude from franking dividend debited to share capital or share premium accounts; an increase in the deduction on infrastructure borrowings from 33c to 36c; and a reduction in the threshold for early remittance of PAYE taxes from $5 million to $1 million.

Let us focus on the infrastructure concession for a moment. The infrastructure borrowings concession will cost over $200 million a year by 1997-98. I think the jury is still out on whether this tax concession is needed or whether the targeting of this tax concession is proper. It sounds like a good idea, but I think we should look at its immediate effect. I see that it has dramatically increased the profitability and attractiveness of tollways.

Suddenly consortiums are falling all over themselves across the country to get on to the tollways gravy train. The recent Citylink agreement between the Victorian government and Transurban, underpinned by this concession, is probably the worst example. Under the contractual agreements with the builder-operator, Transurban, residents, businesses and local authorities will be restricted in their ability to claim compensation for road closures, land acquisition or the obstruction of the Yarra River. State planning laws will not apply and rights to appeal and protest yet again are restricted.

I know this is a state government responsibility, but the fact is the federal tax regime is encouraging this. We ought to take a look at that. Victoria will be able to amend any suburban planning scheme to facilitate Citylink. Local authorities will be left watching on the sidelines. What is more, major thoroughfares will be closed and clearways removed from a number of major roads. Despite Premier Kennett's assertions to the contrary, this will effectively leave many residents with little choice but to use the tollway. As the Melbourne Age said in its editorial last week:

SPEECH.PARA: Most Victorians will draw the conclusion that these measures have been taken because the State Government had to make certain that Transurban was assured of a profit before it would undertake the risk.

This is an astonishing deal from so many angles: the environment, public transport, local democracy, freedom of speech, urban planning, community consultation and so on. I would like to sound a warning. I think we find ourselves being asked to get used to it. Direct deals with private sector developers which override planning laws, which ignore communities and which aim to maximise private returns are unfortunately likely to be an increasing component of urban development in Australia.

PARA.TAB: It is not just because of this. It is thanks to competition policy, but also thanks to the tax concessions on infrastructure borrowings. I can understand why it might have seemed like a great idea in theory, but I wonder if you made allowances for state premiers like Premier Kennett.

The final aspect of this bill I want to address is the reduction in the threshold on early remittance on PAYE tax from $5 million to $1 million. The effect of this amendment is to force thousands of small and medium sized businesses to remit PAYE tax instalments to the tax office fortnightly rather than annually, increasing compliance costs and creating unexpected cash flow problems. The measure, though, will bring forward $275 million from 1996-97 to 1995-96. Quite a clever little measure! It was a major budget measure.

I have to say the Democrats are extremely reluctant to support this measure because it does represent yet another tax impost on small business. It is being done in the absence of the wider context of urgently needed reform to small business taxation. Really, I am getting sick and tired of being asked to vote for legislation in here before the government bothers to respond to wide ranging inquiries which would mean that we might put in place some kind of cohesive response rather than bits and pieces as we go along. It is regrettable.

In the end we are being asked to do this before the government has agreed to reduce the uplift factor on provisional tax. In hearings before the Senate Economics Committee, the tax office tabled documents showing that the result of the excessively high uplift factor is that each year small business is forced to pay about $300 million more in provisional tax than it should, tax on income it never earned.

The Senate inquiry into small business taxation, which Senator Gibson has referred to and which I moved to set up after the 1994 budget, did report in June. It is a good report. It recommends reform of provisional tax, a reduction in the uplift factor and a wide range of other recommendations designed to reduce small business tax compliance costs. But the government has not yet responded to that report. It should have. It should have responded by the end of September.

I would have preferred to see the measure in this bill considered in the context of an overall review of small business taxation which looked at the incidence of tax being collected before the income is earned and looked at the incidence of compliance costs. It would make sense in terms of cohesive, coherent policy. But the government has refused to do this, and the government wonders why the small business community wonder whether it is committed to giving them a fair go.

I urge the government to give some priority to responding to and endorsing the sensible and moderate proposals of the Senate committee, which have widespread support among the small business community and professions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to support my colleague Senator Gibson in offering some comments on the two bills being debated cognately: the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1995 and the Taxation Laws Amendment (FBT Cost of Compliance) Bill 1995. Senator Gibson has foreshadowed in some detail the concerns we have with the legislation and the amendments that we as a coalition will be moving to the bills. I will not go into those in any detail. They will be dealt with in considerable detail in the committee stage.

PARA.TAB: The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) was introduced into the House of Representatives on 29 June of this year. It is an omnibus bill. It has a wide range of amendments to the taxation laws. It includes four measures that were announced in the 1995-96 budget relating to rebateable and frankable dividends, to infrastructure borrowings, to the reduction of the PAYE early remitter threshold and to the issue of depreciation on trading ships. It also deals with changes to the superannuation arrangements that were announced by the government on 28 June. It also encompasses changes to give effect to the announcement made by the Treasurer (Mr Willis) on 26 February of this year of the government's initiative and intention to strengthen and extend the provisions of the law that deny deductions for losses where debts are released under bankruptcy law.

The second bill, the Taxation Laws Amendment (FBT Cost of Compliance) Bill, was introduced a day earlier, on 28 June 1995. It implements the results of the government's review of FBT compliance costs that was announced by the Treasurer on 24 February 1995. That review, which culminated in that report of February 1995, was announced in the May 1994 budget. At that time the government anticipated announcing the results just a couple of months later, in July 1994. But the results were not announced until some seven months later, as I said, in February 1995.

I think that highlights the complexity of the fringe benefits tax as it has grown like Topsy under this government. It also highlights the inevitable consequential resultant very high compliance costs that are imposed on persons, particularly in the small business sector. I share the concern of my colleague Senator Gibson about the great cost that fringe benefits tax impacts upon small business, given the complexity that it covers today.

I think small business has been very harshly treated under the fringe benefits tax because of the growth of the tax and the complexity that is involved. If you ask many small businesses about it, they will tell you that the actual cost of complying with the law is costing them more than the government is raising in revenue. If you have a situation where that is the case, particularly if it is widespread, as it appears to be, then I think you have some very severe problems with the legislation as drafted.

The fringe benefits tax in its original intention was very understandable and accepted because it was part of the necessity of bringing additional equity into the tax laws. But I do think the application of the tax and the growth of the tax—tentacles out everywhere—since then has moved the many parts of the FBT well away from that original understandable and acceptable intention. As a result of that, you have great uncertainty and great cost involved in the compliance with it. One of the commitments of an incoming coalition government is to take the necessary measures to reduce the inordinate compliance costs of FBT, particularly so far as small business is concerned, wherever possible.

The other thing that concerns me about the bills in a general sense is the fact that we are debating them in the second last week of what is a quite frantic session. We have a situation where the government has absolutely lost control of its legislative program. We still have something like not far short of 100 bills, when you add them all up, to deal with in the remaining few days of this session.

The bills we are considering were introduced first into the House of Representatives at the end of June of this year. Some of the elements that they relate to were announced by the government much earlier than that. It is just really another indictment of the government's inability, for whatever reasons, to conduct its legislative program and to program that through the parliament in appropriate and proper due process ways, which is causing a huge backlog here and means that legislation cannot be considered as carefully as it should. It is legislation that affects every taxpayer in Australia in one way or another. It is an indictment of the government that we are being forced to consider not just this legislation but—

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you expect with a Manager of Government Business like we have?

—Yes, we have a problem with the Manager of Government Business in the Senate. That is certainly so, Senator O'Chee, but I think the problems are more deep-rooted than that. I think the real problem is a basic incompetence on the part of the government in terms of managing its legislative program through its own necessary processes, and that culminates in the problems that we have got here. But, of course, the management of the business here is also a compounding factor.

PARA.TAB: The general problem we have in the area of taxation—and these bills reflect part of it—is the huge and inexorable increase in taxation that goes on year in year out under Labor governments. We really ought to be concerned about not just the complexity of the legislation that we are looking at—and that complexity refers to much more than just the fringe benefits tax, to which I have referred. We now have two bills before the house which add pages and pages and pages to the mountain of taxation legislation of this country, which is virtually impossible even for the most exemplary practitioner to come to grips with.

The growth in the taxation laws since this government came to power 12 years ago, almost 13 long hard years ago, is almost inconceivable. It is no wonder that all in the community are labouring, particularly business and especially small business, under the great burden of compliance with government dictate—not only taxation and other laws, but also the whole plethora of regulations and other items of government action that really are a very deadening hand on what ought to be a much more vital growth-oriented economy than the one we have. And it is because of the approach of this government that we do not have that improved economy.

Overriding all of that, as I say, are the inexorable increases we have seen in total government revenue. Of course, those increases have arisen because of the government's seemingly insatiable demand for more and more spending. The government has an appetite for spending which it seems incapable of satisfying. If you are going to increase government spending continually, inevitably you will have to increase the burden on taxpayers to meet the costs associated with that expenditure.

Even the great increases in taxation that we have seen occurring have not been sufficient to meet the government's spending appetite resulting from which we have had enormous budget deficits for many years. Of course, those budget deficits have added to the national debt which, in turn, has caused a major run-down in the national savings. It was said that this year we would have a budget surplus—it was announced in the budget—of about $700 million. That, of course, was after massive sales—

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you planning to cut it? What cuts are you planning to make so that you will not need this revenue?

—We are actually debating your legislation and the policies that you have pursued, Senator Crowley, that have led to this country having a huge national debt again—a debt to the rest of the world—of $180,000 million. He said yesterday on national radio, `We're going to use the superannuation, of which I'm now the boss, to pay off our foreign debt; we're going to knock it off in about four years.' I wonder what is being thought by those Australians who have been of the opinion that they would be secure in their retirement with a proper sensible superannuation arrangement? I wonder what they think of the new you-beaut minister for superannuation saying, `No, don't be silly; we're going to use your superannuation contributions'—with the help of the unions, because the unions are locked into most of it—
—Come on; there are employee trustees on it, and you know it.

—You had better tell your minister for superannuation because he is out on the national airwaves saying that he is going to use the superannuation to pay off the foreign debt that has been incurred as a result of the economic incompetence of this government—and he is going to do it in four years. I do not know when you are retiring, Senator Burns. I would have thought that, with some luck, you might have retired by now. But you have not. PARA.TAB: But the inevitable consequence of what you have done as a government, in terms of your inability to control your own spending, has been to force taxes up every year in a way that is a great burden to the economy, to every individual and, particularly, to every family in Australia, but more particularly lower and middle income families. That applies particularly and most sadly to those who are more in need in our community, particularly the lower income families and those families with children who are trying to get by on a single income. But the sad thing above all of that is that, because of the situation we are now in, we will find that, if by any chance Labor is re-elected at the next election—and heaven forbid—it is absolutely inevitable we will be facing a whole raft of new taxes or increases in existing taxes. Will you be bringing bring back the iniquitous tax on builders hardware items that you tried to impose this year and which would have hit every Australian, but for the good grace and commonsense of the Senate in rejecting that legislation?

TALK.START.PARA: —You tell me about your $10 million cuts, Senator. Tell me about your cuts.

—Will you be imposing a capital gains tax on the family home, as has been mooted time and time again over the years by spokesmen on your side of politics? Given the growing strength of the left wing within your party, Senator Crowley, will you be imposing the wealth taxes that have been the dream of your left wing for many years? PARA.TAB: In concluding my remarks on these bills, whilst we look at individual bills and in the context of the complexity and detail of those bills—and it is very necessary that we do so, and I believe that the Senate plays a major role in those examinations—I congratulate my colleagues Senator Watson and Senator Chapman, but also Senator Spindler from the Australian Democrats, for the excellent minority report they produced on the Taxation Laws Amendment (FBT Cost of Compliance) Bill. I also congratulate my colleague Senator Gibson on the terrific work that he has been doing in these areas as well.

It is hard to keep the other side of politics honest. When it comes to taxation measures those opposite are absolute pirates. They tell you one day, as they did before the 1993 election, that they are not going to increase any taxes but come Monday, after being re-elected, the Prime Minister and the Treasurer work out how best they can undo their tax promise of major income tax cuts promised before the election which were enshrined in l-a-w, law, and which were to be introduced on 1 January 1996. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating cognately two bills—the Taxation Laws Amendment (FBT Cost of Compliance) Bill 1995 and the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1995. Had these bills not been introduced so late into the parliamentary session, each of these pieces of legislation would have been dealt with separately. So there is pressure, as usual, towards the end of the year, and in such a pressure cooker environment there is always the problem of not properly attending to each of the specific items because they are substantial in themselves.

PARA.TAB: Speaking initially on the cost of compliance legislation and then on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3), it is with a great deal of relief that the government, under overwhelming opposition from those affected, has withdrawn schedule 2 from the bill. Schedule 2 covered those most iniquitous living away from home allowance proposals. Fortunately, they are now out. This result is due to the proper use of the Senate committee system whereby certain legislation is referred to a review committee, which gives those affected by the legislation a great opportunity to present their views, under cross-examination, to the parliament. It is an important segment of democracy.

The original proposal, we believe on this side of politics—and I am glad the government has now acceded to this particular view—was impractical because it set some very arbitrary limits and it really did not reflect commercial practice. There was also a greatly increased cost to employers, falling principally on contractors, who could have been up for an additional $50 million had those LIFA provisions not been amended, and also the mining industry. Furthermore, the original proposal would have caused general disharmony in industrial relations right across Australia.

I think today is an appropriate opportunity to acknowledge some of the very fine presentations that obviously persuaded the government to change its mind. I thank Senator Short and Senator Gibson for their comments. The title of the bill, I remind the Senate, includes the words `cost of compliance' because the cost of compliance weighs very heavily on all taxpayers across Australia not only for income tax but increasingly for fringe benefit tax. This is indeed a serious issue.

I believe this increasing cost of compliance is something that this government is going to have to live with. It is fairly unique to Australia. While perhaps some other countries might be getting their costs of compliance down, ours is escalating at a most unacceptable rate. In addition to paying our tax, we are paying effectively a secondary tax in the form of having to devote all those resources just to comply with taxes. Fringe benefit is not a good example because in a number of areas, particularly in car parking, the costs of compliance for some firms actually exceed the taxes they pay to government. That is indeed a very bad tax. The government stands condemned on its track record in terms of increasing the cost of compliance.

Last week I drew to the attention of the Senate a speech by Richard Buchanan, a distinguished former president of the Tax Institute of Australia. Throughout that address he frequently drew attention to the burden on taxpayers, particularly business, in having to comply with tax legislation, particularly the FBT.

The government has actually sought a great deal of mileage from this particular piece of legislation, particularly from its decision to remove lap-top computers and mobile phones when those phones are used principally for business or employment and also certain after-hours taxi costs. But those concessions are offset by an increase in the statutory rate for calculating car benefits provided to employees. What are regarded as minor benefits have also been withdrawn.

The point I wish to make is that those concessions should never in the first place have been subject to the fringe benefit tax regime. This government set out to tax fringe benefits on remuneration packages, but it has grown to be a tax on a lot more than just remuneration packages. The other concessions include—and I give the government its due—portable computers, protective clothing required for employment, briefcases, calculators, tools of trade, subscriptions to trade and professional journals, airport lounge membership, business related software, electronic diaries and corporate card membership fees.

Just to give you some idea of the ludicrous extent to which the fringe benefit tax regime extended, when a boss provided sunscreens and sun hats to protect his employees working in the sun, he was required to pay fringe benefits tax on those sorts of expenditures. That was absolutely outrageous. It was not conducive to employers providing these sorts of things. That is what I mean by the ludicrous nature, unhealthy nature, of some of these fringe benefit applications.

Those sorts of fringe benefits were so unreal and so un-Australian that the government eventually was forced to change its mind in relation to, say, protective clothing, taking that out as a fringe benefit. In other words, if a council provides a council worker with sunscreen and hats, no longer does the employer have to pay a fringe benefits tax.

It was interesting to note—and I think I should share this with the Senate—that the Tourism Council of Australia raised three significant issues in relation to fringe benefits: firstly, the income tax and the fringe benefit treatment of the benefits not between employer and employee but with third parties is increasingly complex. When a benefit is provided to an employee by a third party it really should be taken out of the fringe benefit tax regime, as a simple solution, and transferred to income tax so the person who gets the benefit from a third party pays income tax. That would certainly ease the fringe benefits tax on tourism greatly.

Secondly, the Tourism Council mentioned having the normal accounting year, which is 1 July through to 30 June, as an option in addition to the already prescribed fringe benefits year, which, as you know, is different from the financial year because the fringe benefit year runs from 1 April through to 31 March. It should not be mandatory but optional. In such a case, it could have a great deal of merit for some firms in reducing compliance costs. I think it should be noted and picked up by the government. Thirdly, the time for lodgment of the fringe benefit tax return is just too tight given the range of benefits that are now subject to fringe benefit tax plus the sheer complexity of the legislation that ordinary businessmen, who are not necessarily accountants, have to adhere to.

In terms of criticism of where the fringe benefits tax is going, I draw on what Corporate Tax Australia's respected tax spokesman Bob Bryant said. He believes that there was a lost opportunity in the cost of compliance review that the government undertook. It resulted in the removal of those so-called minor fringe benefits from the fringe benefit tax regime. He believes that the government really did not tackle such issues as business entertainment. The government has failed to correct the underlying FBT policy which has increasingly strayed into the non-remunerative area.

While the government made these minor concessions it sought to neutralise the effect of the loss. In effect it is going to collect a lot more money because it is going to increase the statutory rate for calculating car benefits provided to employees. The cost of providing those benefits, according to the Taxpayers Association, is on average 10 per cent and, in some cases, as high as 17 per cent. It is quite significant.

Honourable senators would be aware that nine years ago the government introduced the fringe benefits tax concept where the responsibility for payment fell not on the person who got the benefit but on the employer who provided the benefit or an association or third party that provided a benefit. We are really getting into an unreal situation. Nine years ago we had this significant change.

It was introduced with all the ulterior equity motives of improving tax equity. Since that time it has been revenue driven. It has become a major revenue earner estimated to yield over $3.23 billion in the current financial year. At the same time it is going to add hundreds of thousands of dollars in tax compliance.

I submit that the amendments before the Senate already add to the corporate problems associated with the provision of entertainment. The new provisions apply only to meal entertainment—that is, food and drink. This is going to add further to this compliance difficulty. You have to excise the cost of the drink and food from, for example, the taxi cost involved in getting to the place and also if there was any deemed recreation part of that function.

Under the proposals, an employer may choose one of three methods where meal entertainment is provided: firstly, a ratio based on a 12-week record keeping log book style; secondly, a 50/50 split; or, thirdly, the actual expenditure. There is a real problem with the 50/50 split because the FBT is payable on all employees' meal entertainment regardless of whether it is deductible or non-deductible for income tax purposes. You have the ludicrous situation of a non-deductible item which you have to pay fringe benefits tax on.

The Taxpayers Association of Australia warns that taxpayers should be very wary of these new rules as it is possible that they may result in high FBT costs if the wrong method is chosen. You are really forcing ordinary businessmen to go out and seek the best professional advice on choosing the most appropriate method of accounting for their fringe benefits tax—that is, choosing between option one, two or three. Around 35 million hectares are affected by acidification each year, and over 55 million hectares of moderately acidic soil are at risk of becoming highly acidic, with a pH of less than 4.8. At this level, plant growth and farm yield begin to decline dramatically. Reduced crop cover can contribute to erosion, further damaging soils. New South Wales already has 13.5 million hectares of highly acidic soil; Queensland, 8.4 million hectares; and WA, 4.7 million hectares of highly acidic soil.

Operating or recurring expenditures are made in the course of trade to produce business revenue. These are payments usually made on a regular basis. An example is the cost of fertiliser used to improve a crop or pasture.

This is a correct definition of capital expenditure, but the problem is that it appears to exclude such things as periodic five- to 10-year applications of lime to fields. Taken with a restriction under operating expenses, it seems to exclude liming for acidification completely.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Taxation Office has this explanation. They were asked for piecemeal definitions by staff at Primary Industries and Energy. The current farm gate value of the Tasmanian apple industry is around $60 million, with an estimated flow-on value of $97 million to the state. The cider tax was announced as a result of the inquiry into the wine industry, where long and detailed assessment was made as to whether or not a wine tax ought be introduced. The result of that was anti there should not be such a tax.

So what did the federal government do? Without any consultation with the apple growers or with the cider industry and none of the courtesies extended to the wine industry, they simply made the decision that there would be a tax on cider. Why was there no consultation? Why were the people, especially in Tasmania, ignored by the Labor government? The basis of their decision defies all logic, because one would have thought that a fruit wine, be it from grapes or apples, ought be treated in the same manner.

Undoubtedly the Labor Party has read some of the polling and is of the view that a lot of the Tasmanian seats will fall anyway and they therefore might as well try to bolster the wine industry and some grape growing areas in South Australia and elsewhere and write off some Tasmanian seats. But that is not the way you ought to govern this country. The apple industry clearly deserves better.

I congratulate the Liberal candidate for Franklin, Les Glover, on the initiative that he took last weekend and for the very real input that he has had into my party processes. I note that he issued a media release today indicating that the Liberal Party is opposed to new taxes and increasing taxes. Therefore I have every hope that, once the legislation is introduced by Labor and we see the fine print of it, it will be opposed not only as being a discriminatory tax but also as being one that could deal a very real blow to further employment opportunities, especially in my home state of Tasmania and in particular in the electorate of Franklin.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week honourable senators will recall that I read to the Senate a statement by Mr Paul Berry of Moonah in Tasmania and indicated that I would provide further information with regard to an accusation that Mr Berry is making about the case of Sydney Sparkes Orr, a case which is notorious in the history of Tasmania. I continue Mr Berry's accusation with a verbatim reading of an accusation which he has published in the state of Tasmania and I bring it to the Senate tonight. I quote directly from a document provided to me by Mr Berry. It is entitled Accusation, and it reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: I, Christopher Paul Berry, of 45 Sixth Avenue, Moonah West in Tasmania, do make Oath and say:-
1. THAT in the case of Sydney Sparkes Orr v. University of Tasmania, No. 278 of 1956, the said Professor Orr was denied justice.

2. THAT he was denied justice by wilful and calculated disregard of certain evidence or of the import of such evidence, by the trial Judge in the Supreme Court of Tasmania, Mr. Justice (later Sir,) Richard Kenneth Green.

3. THAT upon Professor Orr's Appeal, heard in the high Court of Australia in May of 1957, the Judges of the High Court hearing that Appeal, did likewise knowingly and deliberately disregard that same evidence or the import of that same evidence. They had, however, acknowledged that the issues were mainly not issues of law but of fact.
4. THAT by their refusal to follow normal processes of ratiocination, justice was thereby further and finally denied to Professor Orr, even at this, the highest level to which he had access.

5. THAT Professor Orr's original summary dismissal resulted from a process of so-called inquiry, but in which proper inquiry in a manner appropriate to a matter of such acknowledged gravity, was not pursued. In finding as he did, that neither the Kemp Committee inquiry nor the Vice-Chancellor's inquiry into the Milanov, Townsley and Tanner allegations was conducted according to the Statutes of the University, I claim support from Judge Green.
6. THAT Professor Orr, in the Kemp Committee inquiry was denied natural justice.

7. THAT the true purpose of this Inquiry would appear to have been, less the ascertaining of the truth than the contrived rationalisation of frame-up. This was under the guidance of Solicitor-General Stanley Burbury and the Chancellor of the University, Mr. H. S. (Later Sir Henry) Baker, M.L.C.
8. THAT there would appear to have been conspiracy against Professor Orr.

9. THAT Stanley Charles Burbury, (later to be made K.B.E., K.C.V.O. & K.C.M.G.) who at the time of the Kemp Committee inquiry was Solicitor-General for Tasmania, would appear to have been involved in such conspiracy as alleged.
10. THAT the said Stanley Burbury could appear to have been involved in the furtherance of such conspiracy as alleged, by other criminal means.

11. THAT Reginald Kemp, Suzanne Kemp and Geoffrey Allison would appear to have been manipulated in the bringing forward of allegations against Professor Orr to the University inquiry; and that such manipulation would appear to have been by means akin to blackmail.
12. THAT similarly, they would appear to have been under duress in the giving of sworn evidence in the Supreme Court in support of the University defence.

13. THAT Suzanne Kemp, both at the University inquiry and later in her sworn evidence, did endeavour to indicate that her purported allegations against Professor Orr did not in fact apply to Professor Orr at all. In this, I say, she was steadfastly ignored.

14. THAT the said Suzanne Kemp endeavoured to show, and to show in a manner which could not be controverted, that her evidence did in fact relate to a real person other than Professor Orr, and with whom, her sworn evidence suggested, she had some kind of relationship. I do not refer to Geoffrey Allison. In this too, she was apparently wilfully disbelieved, despite the judicial pretence that she was believed.
15. THAT, had Suzanne Kemp's efforts been acknowledged for what they signified, a finding against Professor Orr that he seduced Miss Kemp would have been impossible.

16. THAT, whilst Professor Orr's case against the University lay sub judice, a certain `Diary' or purported diary of Suzanne Kemp for 1955, was altered and thereby falsified. This was between the month of March 1956 and October 1956, when Professor Orr's case came on for trial, or so it would appear. It could, however, have been altered even after the trial commenced. It would appear that such alteration was not made upon the initiative of Miss Kemp, and was therefore without fault on her part. By means of such falsification, vital evidence in Professor Orr's favour was suppressed.

17. THAT Stanley Burbury would appear to have had knowledge of such suppression of evidence. He was on the Committee advising and instructing the lawyers involved in the preparation of the University defence. I say that it is inconceivable that such alteration and suppression would have been made without his knowledge and approval.

18. THAT in addition, and during the same period in 1956, the so-called diary for 1955 was altered in such a manner as to amount to the fabrication of evidence, capable of being interpreted to Professor Orr's disadvantage.
19. THAT Stanley Burbury should be presumed to have had knowledge of such fabrication of evidence and to have been party to it.
20. THAT Judge Green chose to ignore the obvious suppression of vital evidence, and that in addition he chose to misinterpret the fabricated evidence to Professor Orr's disadvantage.

21. THAT he unreasonably yet deliberately accepted the so-called diary as affording that confirmation which he acknowledged as being essential to the acceptance of viva voce evidence given by Miss Kemp.

22. THAT during the period when Orr's case lay sub judice, Stanley Burbury was appointed to and accepted the position of Chief Justice of Tasmania; and that it must be concluded that such appointment could have affected both the conduct and outcome of Professor Orr's case against the University of Tasmania.

23. THAT Judge Green suspended reason and abandoned impartiality towards Orr, in that he knowingly and deliberately ignored those clues in Miss Kemp's evidence by which she gave indication that an incident on the beach at Bellerive in August of 1955, did not involve Professor Orr, but, instead, involved another person whose existence had been obscured by the suppression of evidence in the alteration of the diary. I state that Miss Kemp, in the giving of her evidence would appear to have been in effect, blackmailed over this other person.

24. THAT by reason of blatant disregard by Judge Green of the date established by the unchallenged evidence of one, Noel Edward Gathercole, Judge Green took the liberty of finding that the said incident had involved Professor Orr, the obvious impossibility of its having done so notwithstanding

25. THAT, having regard to apparent conspiracy, blackmail, suppression of and fabrication of evidence as heretofore alleged, all other unsupported allegations in Miss Kemp's evidence as to incidents elsewhere than at Bellerive, should be regarded as no more than thistledown; apparently supplied on demand.

26. THAT the Judges of the High Court of Australia: Dixon C.J., together with Williams and Taylor J.J., did likewise resort to wilful disregard of certain of Miss Kemp's 7 evidence, in such a manner and to such effect as to lead them to support and affirm Judge Green's absurd mishandling of the materials before him.
27. THAT the High Court Judgement therefore contained and re-inforced the same absurdity with regard to Bellerive, such as had been a feature of the original Judgement of Green J.

28. THAT the Judges of the High Court would appear to have been aware of this; inasmuch as they even pretended that this same obvious absurdity amounted to an incident especially damning of Professor Orr. That they concurred in such absurdity, I allege tends to support belief in conspiracy, even on their part.
29. THAT it must appear that they did this with the intention of lending their authority; the authority of the High Court of Australia, to the cover-up of crime.

30. THAT, in the ultimate, it must appear that the High Court judges were deliberately choosing to cover-up for Chief Justice Burbury of Tasmania, even though this had to be by way of denying justice to Professor Orr: the new Chief Justice of Tasmania being at considerable risk were the matter to have been decided in Professor Orr's favour.

31. THAT various arms of Government in Tasmania would appear to have been engaged in cover-up; by attempt either to discredit or to frame such critics as the Deponent hereof, by means of a shooting incident in December 1959, at the home of Professor Orr.
32. THAT I express my willingness to appear before any inquiry such as a Royal Commission, in order that I might adduce evidence and argument in support of the allegations contained herein.
Then there is reference to `Stanley Burbury, KBE, KCVO, KCMG, Solicitor-General, Chief Justice, and, ultimately, Governor of the State of Tasmania'. It continues:

Lest it be thought that the above allegations be utterly beyond belief, I make further allegation regarding the conduct, and by implication, the character of Stanley Burbury. In doing so, I claim liberty under the provisions of Sec. 206. l.(d) of the Tasmanian Criminal Code Act, 1924, relating to Fair Comment; and I claim this liberty also with regard to comment concerning legal practitioner John Bruce Piggott.

I will conclude there for this evening, Mr President, but I indicate that there is a little more that I will bring to the attention of the Senate at the next available opportunity. It is important to read this in its entirety.(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say, Mr President, that I am absolutely staggered to hear this particular allegation being read into the Hansard. Unfortunately, I was not here at the beginning of Senator Bell's dissertation but I really query what he is on about.

PARA.TAB: This matter was settled some 40-odd years ago. Bringing it up now and mentioning all these names causes embarrassment and a great deal of concern to the Allison and Kemp families, not to mention the family of a former Chief Justice and Governor of Tasmania, the late Stanley Burbury, and other people who were mentioned, such as Mr Piggott and three High Court judges. I know we are protected by parliamentary privilege but I think Senator Bell has taken things a bit far here.

I would query why this particular person, Mr Berry, would make these allegations 40 years after the event and why he has chosen to do it in this particular way. Using parliamentary privilege is very questionable. If the evidence had any substance whatsoever, I would have thought the matter could be handled by the police. But in this particular case the process of the parliament is being used, and I do not believe it is meant to be used in that way.

I look forward to hearing whatever else Senator Bell has to say about this matter. But at this stage, on behalf of quite a lot of people in Tasmania, including a former Governor, High Court judges and certain well known families who have suffered a lot over this particular matter—not to mention the fact there was a film made about it—I can only say that this matter should have been well and truly put to rest. For it to be brought up in such a way is highly questionable. I question Senator Bell's motives. I know an election is coming up but I do not think that this is the sort of publicity he is looking for.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise on this debate on the adjournment to highlight a major deficiency in a vital public service to this country. The weather bureau is in serious trouble and senior officers have revealed this in spades in the annual report this year. This document reveals that the ALP government is making financial cuts to the services of the weather bureau which are having very dangerous effects.

PARA.TAB: Senator Faulkner was fully questioned about this in the estimates process last week but all he could say was, `We are going to have an inquiry into it.' He does not need an inquiry because the annual report lays the record bare for everyone to see. It reveals an appalling state of affairs with the Bureau of Meteorology complaining about systematic cuts to its budget over many years. A desperate bureau is increasingly critical of this government. It is virtually without precedent in annual reports that a government department would be so desperate to be so critical. Let's see why.

The bureau can no longer guarantee that dangerous weather warnings will be issued. I remind the Senate and the Australian people that we are talking about storm warnings, wind warnings, hailstorm warnings, fire risk warnings. Given the nature of this country and its extremes in weather, it is not too hard to see that if this situation were to continue, not only would it put people's livelihoods in jeopardy, it would put lives in jeopardy.

The weather bureau's report does reveal the extent of the cuts. The report said that, from the 1993-94 budget to the 1995-96 budget, funding was decreased from $117 million to $112 million, a cut of $5 million. This cut was not just a one-off. It has been going on systematically over the years through what the government calls its efficiency dividend.

It is fine for government departments to be efficient—that is laudable—and sometimes funding needs to be cut for them to become more efficient. They sometimes need to cut the fat out. But, in this case, what the government has done is cut the effectiveness of the organisation, and that is something a government should never do, particularly when it affects a service as vital to Australia as the weather bureau. Let us look at what the bureau's own annual report said the effects of all this were. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the impacts of staff and operational funding reductions began to cut deeply into the quality . . . and the reliability of the basic data collection.

The quality and reliability were affected. Isn't that a damning statement? And it came from the bureau itself. The government's $5 million efficiency dividend this year is ripping the guts out of an essential, life-preserving service to Australia.

PARA.TAB: The cut in funding—apart from affecting the day-to-day services that people in Australia need—is also drastically affecting long-term weather and climate predictions. In a country which has one of the driest climates in the world, and probably one of the most vulnerable climates in the world, this is an act of administrative vandalism. The government is compromising the standard of data collection, and the ongoing climate record will actually have gaps. We have international obligations to provide accurate data that will form part of a world pattern of data collection.

We are supposed to be one of the wealthiest countries in the world but, because of what this government has done to the country over the last 13 years, we find that we have a vital public service that is not funded properly, so it cannot fulfil its full role. As I indicated earlier, all that Minister Faulkner could say at the estimates hearing was, `We are going to review it.' That is not acceptable. That review is not needed because the review is already in the annual report and it points the government in the direction it should be going.

The weather bureau has the function of maintaining reliable and high quality data, both in terms of immediate weather records and long-term climate records. This government is now placing Australians at risk by not allowing this department to function effectively. Dr Zillman, from the bureau, is obviously appalled, given the tone of his own annual report. It is the responsibility of us in the Senate to make the public aware that this government is not performing yet again in another area. This is yet another reason for a change at the next election.

Branch members in either Victoria OR Western Australia haven't had a chance to pass judgement on these extraordinary happenings in Perth and Melbourne. that is, in the branch office—

at an alarming pace. No accurate figures are available, but informed guesses have Branch membership at less than half the 1990 membership (i.e. less than 8,750 financial). On top of this, AWU-FIME National Executive have attempted to merge the Western Australian and Victorian Branches of the AWU—and unify control in a small Divisional Executive. The NSW AWU Branch had over a million dollars in investment, it owned properties including it's own office building and had a healthy membership, giving the trend of the size of Unions these days.

The Branch Executives was made up of some paid officials and a fixed proportion of Rank and File members which ensured that the Union did not become directed by professional officers to the detriment of members. The members were receiving a good level of service.

Because of the treachery of the `National Secretaries', Steve Harrison and Michael Forshaw, the amalgamation was completed without the NSW AWU Federal Branch being fully consulted on the final issue of the amalgamation or the `Rules' of the amalgamated Unions.

This led to a set of Rules being drawn up mainly by FIME's legal council and a member of the `Executive Council' without the protection of advice from the AWU Solicitors, Carroll and O'Dea which was a requirement that the NSW AWU Branch Executive had made a condition of the negotiations.
The result was:

2.The amalgamated Branch Executive of the AWU—FIME had a voting bias of 32 to 14 in favour of FIME.

3.Manipulation of Union Elections resulted in the fact that FIME Office Holders would stay in the office until 1997, yet the AWU office holders had to go to election in 1995, with FIME members entitled to nominate and vote in the ballot for positions on the AWU Executive. PARA.TAB: I also have a letter here signed by T.J.
